div.p: CITY-HEIRESS: OR, Sir Timothy Treat-all. A COMEDY. As it is Acted At his Royal Highness his THEATRE.

LONDON: Printed for D. Brown, at the Black Swan and Bible without Temple-bar; and T. Benskin in St. Brides Church-yard; and H. Rhodes next door to the Bear-Tavern neer Bride-lane in Fleetstreet. 1682.

div.head: To the Right Honourable Henry Earl of Arundel, and Lord Mowbray.
div.p:
'TIs long that I have with great impatience waited some opportunity to declare my infinite Respect to your Lordship; coming, I may say, into the World with a Veneration for your Illustrious Family, and being brought up with continual Praises of the Renowned Actions of your glorious Ancestors, both in War and Peace, so famous over the Christian World for their Vertue, Piety, and Learning, their elevated Birth, and greatness of Courage, and of whom all our English History are full of the Wonders of their Lives: A Family of so ancient Nobility, and from whom so many Hero's have proceeded to bless and serve their King and Country, that all Ages and all Nations mention 'em even with Adoration. My self have been in this our Age an Eye and Ear-witness, with what Transports of Joy, with what unusual Respect and Ceremony, above what we pay to Mankind, the very Name of the Great Howards of Norfolk and Arundel, have been celebrated on Forein Shores! And when any one of your Illustrious Family have pass'd the Streets, the People throng'd to praise and bless him, as soon as his Name has been made known to the glad Croud. This I have seen with a Joy that became a true English heart, (who truly venerate its brave Country-men) and joyn'd my dutiful Respects and Praises with the most devout; but never had the happiness yet of any opportunity to express particularly that Admiration I have and ever had for your Lordship and your Great Family. Still, I say, I did
admire you, still I wisht and pray'd for you; 'twas all I cou'd or durst: But as my Esteem for your Lordship dayly increas'd with my Judgment, so nothing cou'd bring it to a more absolute height and perfection, than to observe in these troublesome times, this Age of Lying, Peaching, and Swearing, with what noble Prudence, what steadiness of Mind, what Loyalty and Conduct you have evaded the Snare, that 'twas to be fear'd was laid for all the Good, the Brave, and Loyal, for all that truly lov'd our best of Kings and this distracted Country. A thousand times I have wept for fear that Impudence and Malice wou'd extend so far as to stain your Noble and ever-Loyal Family with its unavoidable Imputations; and as often for joy, to see how undauntedly both the Illustrious Duke your Father, and your self, stem'd the raging Torrent that threatned, with yours, the ruine of the King and Kingdom; all which had not power to shake your Constancy or Loyalty: for which, may Heaven and Earth reward and bless you; the noble Examples to thousands of failing hearts, who from so great a President of Loyalty, became confirm'd. May Heaven and Earth bless you for your pious and resolute bravery of Mind, and heroick Honesty, when you cry'd, Not guilty; that you durst, like your great self, speak Conscientious Truths in a Juncto so vitious, when Truth and Innocence was criminal: and I doubt not but the Soul of that great Sufferer bows down from Heaven in gratitude for that noble service done it. All these and a thousand marks you give of dayly growing Greatness; every day produces to those like me, curious to learn the Story of your Life and Actions, something that even adds a Lustre to your great Name, which one wou'd think cou'd be made no more splendid: some new Goodness, some new act of Loyalty or Courage, comes out
to cheer the World and those that admire you. Nor wou'd I be the last of those that dayly congratulate and celebrate your rising Glory; nor durst I any other way approach you with it, but this humble one, which carries some Excuse along with it.

Proud of the opportunity then, I most humbly beg your Lordships Patronage of a Comedy, which has nothing to defend it, but the Honour it begs; and nothing to deserve that Honour, but its being in every part true Tory! Loyal all-over! except one Knave, which I hope no body will take to himself; or if he do, I must e'en say, with Hamlet, — Then let the strucken Deer go weep— It has the luck to be well receiv'd in the Town; which (not from my Vanity) pleases me, but that thereby I find Honesty begins to come in fashion again, when Loyalty is approv'd, and Whigism becomes a Jest where'er 'tis met with. And no doubt on't, so long as the Royal Cause has such Patrons as your Lordship, such vigorous and noble Supporters, his Majesty will be great, secure and quiet, the Nation flourishing and happy, and seditious Fools and Knaves that have so long disturb'd the Peace and Tranquility of the World, will become the business and sport of Comedy, and at last the scorn of that Rabble that fondly and blindly worshipt 'em; and whom nothing can so well convince as plain Demonstration, which is ever more powerful and prevailent than Precept, or even Preaching it self. If this have edifi'd effectual, 'tis all I wish; and that your Lordship will be pleas'd to accept the humble Offering, is all I beg, and the greatest Glory I care shou'd be done.

closer.signed: Your Lordships most Humble and most Obedient Servant, A. BEHN.

div.head: THE PROLOGUE, Written by Mr. Otway.
SPOKEN by Mrs. BARRY.
div.l: HOW vain have prov'd the Labours of the Stage,
In striving to reclaim a vitious Age!
Poets may write the Mischief to impeach,
You care as little what the Poets teach,
As you regard at Church what Parsons preach.
But where such Follies and such Vices reign,
What honest Pen has patience to refrain?
At Church, in Pews, ye most devoutly snore,
And here, got dully drunk, ye come to roar;
Ye go to Church to glout, and Ogle there,
And come to meet more lewd convenient here:
With equal Zeal ye honour either place,
And run so very evenly your Race,
Y' improve in Wit just as you do in Grace.
It must be so, some Daemon has possest
Our Land, and we have never since been blest.
Y' have seen it all, or heard of its Renown,
In reverend shape it stalk'd about the Town,
Six Yeomen tall attending on its frown.
Sometimes with humble note and zealous lore,
'Twou'd play the Apostolick Function o'er:
But, Heav'n have mercy on us when it swore.
Whene'er it swore, to prove the Oaths were true,
Out of its mouth at random Halters flew
Round some unwary neck, by Magick thrown,
Though still the cunning Devil sav'd its own:
For when the Inchantment could no longer last,
The subtile Pug, most dexterously uncast,
Left awful form for one more seeming pious,
And in a moment vary'd to defie us:
From silken Doctor, home-spun Ananias
Left the lewd Court, and did in City fix,
Where still by its old Arts it plays new Tricks,
And fills the heads of Fools with Politicks.
This Daemon lately drew in many a Guest,
To part with zealous Guinny for— no Feast.
Who, but the most incorrigible Fops,
For ever doom'd in dismal Cells, call'd Shops,
To cheat and damn themselves to get their Livings,
Wou'd lay sweet Money out in Sham-Thanksgivings?
Sham-Plots you may have paid for o'er and o'er;
But who ere paid for a Sham-Treat before?
Had you not better sent your Offerings all,
Hither to us, than Sequestrators Hall?
I being your Steward, Iustice had been done ye;
I cou'd have entertain'd you worth your Money.

div.head: THE CITY-HEIRESS: OR, Sir Timothy Treat-all.
ACT the First.
SCENE the First. The Street.
div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy Treat-all, followed by Tom Wilding, bare, Sir Charles Meriwill, Foppington, and Footman with a Cloak.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: TRouble me no more: for I am resolv'd, deaf and obdurate, d● see, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I beseech ye, Uncle, hear me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Dear Uncle—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You will be mortifi'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: At least hear me out, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No, I have heard you out too often, Sir, till you have talkt me out of ma● a fair thousand; have had ye out of all the Bayliffs, Serjeants, and Constables clutches bout Town, Sir; have brought ye out of all the Surgeons, Apothecaries, and Pox Doctors hands, that ever pretended to cure incurable Diseases; and have crost ye ou● the Books of all the Mercers, Silk-men, Exchange-men, Taylors, Shoemakers, and So strisses; with all the rest of the unconscionable City-tribe of the long Bill, that had Faith enough to trust, and thought me Fool enough to pay.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: But, Sir, consider, he's your own Flesh and Bloud.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: That's more than I'll swear.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Your onely Heir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: That's more than you or any of his wise Associates can tell, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why his wise Associates? have you any exception to the Company he keeps? This reflects on me and young Dresswell, Sir, men both of Birth and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why, good Sir Charles Meriwill, let me tell you, since you'll have it out, That you and young Dresswell are able to debauch, destroy, and confound all the young imitating Fops in Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay, never huff, Sir; for I have six thousand pound a year, and value no man: Neither do I speak so much for your particular, as for the Company you keep, such Tarmagant Tories as these, [to Foping.] who are the very Vermine of a young Heir, and for one Tickling give him a thousand Bites.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Death! meaning me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes, you, Sir. Nay, never stare, Sir; I fear you not: no mans hectoring signifies this— in the City, but the Constable's; no body dares be sawcy here, except it be in the Kings name.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Sir, I confess he was to blame.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Sir Charles, thanks to Heaven, you may be lewd, you have a plentiful Estate, may whore, drink, game, and play the Devil; your Uncle Sir Anthony Meriwill intends to give you all his Estate too: But for such Sparks as this, and my Fop in fashion here, why with what Face, Conscience, or Religion, can they be lewd and vitious, keep their Wenches, Coaches, rich Liveries, and so forth, who live upon Charity, and the Sins of he Nation?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: If he have Youthful Vices, he has Vertues too.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes, he had; but I know not, you have bewitcht him amongst ye [weeping.] before he fell to Toryism, he was a sober civil Youth, and had some Religion in him, wou'd read ye Prayers night and morning with a laudable voice, and cry Amen to 'em; wou'd have done ones heart good to have heard him:— Wore decent Cloaths; was ●unk but upon Fasting-nights, and swore but on Sundays and Holy-days: and then I ●d hopes of him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Aye, Heaven forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: But, Sir, he's now become a new man, is casting off all his Women, is ●unk not above five or six times a week, swears not above once in a quarter of an hour, or has not gam'd this two days.—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: 'Twas because the Devil was in's Pocket then.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: — Begins to take up at Coffee-houses, talks gravely in the City, speaks indalous●y of the Government, and rails most abominably against the Pope and the ench King.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Aye, aye, this shall not wheedle me out of one English Guinny; and so I told ●n yesterday.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You did so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes; by a good token you were witty upon me, and swore I lov'd and ho●r'd the King nowhere but on his Coin.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Is it possible, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: God forgive me, Sir; I confess I was a little overtaken.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Aye, so it shou'd seem: for he mistook his own Chamber, and went to bed to Maids.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How! to bed to your Maids! Sure, Sir, 'tis scandal on him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No, no, he makes his brags on't, Sir. Oh that crying sin of Boasting! Well fare, I say, the days of old Oliver; he by a wholsome Act, made it death to boast; so that then a man might whore his heart out, and no body the wiser.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Right, Sir, and then the men pass'd for sober religious persons, and the women for as demure Saints—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Aye, then there was no scandal; but now they do not onely boast what they do, but what they do not.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll take care that fault shall be mended, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Aye, so will I, if Poverty have any feats of Mortification; and so farewel to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Stay, Sir, are you resolved to be so cruel then, and ruine all my Fortunes now depending?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Most religiously—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You are?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Death, I'll rob.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Do and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, I'll turn Papist.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Do and be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Bless me, Sir, what a scandal would that be to the Family of the Treatalls!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hum! I had rather indeed he turn'd Turk or Jew, for his own sake; but as for scandalizing me, I defie it: my Integrity has been known ever since Forty One; I bought three thousand a year in Bishops Lands, as 'tis well known, and lost it at the Kings return; for which I'm honour'd by the City. But for his farther satisfaction, consolation, and distruction, know, That I Sir Timothy Treat-all, Knight and Alderman, do think my self young enough to marry, d'ye see, and will wipe your Nose with a Son and Heir of my own begetting, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Death! marry!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Patience, dear Tom, or thou't spoil all.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Damn him, I've lost all Patience, and can dissemble no longer, though I lose all,— Very good, Sir; heark ye, I hope she's young and handsome; or if she be not, amongst the numerous lusty-stomacht Whigs that dayly nose your publick Dinners, some may be found that either for Money, Charity, or Gratitude, may requite your Treats. You keep open house to all the Party, not for Mirth, Generosity, or good Nature, but for Roguery. You cram the Brethren, the pious City-Gluttons, with good Cheer, good Wine, and Rebellion in abundance, gormandizing all Comers and Goers, of all Sexes, Sorts, Opinions, and Religions, young half-witted Fops, hot-headed Fools, and Malecontents: You guttle and fawn on all, and all in hopes of debauching the Kings Liege-people into Commonwealths-men; and rather than lose a Convert, you'll pimp for him. These are your nightly Debauches.— Nay, rather than you shall want it, I'll cuckold you my self in pure Revenge.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How! Cuckold his own natural Uncle!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Oh, he cannot be so prophane.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
Prophane! why he deni'd but now the having any share in me; and therefore 'tis lawful. I am to live by my wits, you say, and your old rich good-natur'd
Cuckold is as sure a Revenue to a handsome young Cadet, as a thousand pound a year. Your tolerable face and shape is an Estate in the City, and a better Bank than your Six per Cent. at any time.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since Nature has furnisht you so well, you need but up and ride, show and be rich; and so your Servant, witty Mr. Wilding.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Whilst I am labouring anothers good, I quite neglect my own. This cursed, proud, disdainful Lady Galliard, is ever in my head; she's now at Church, I'm sure, not for Devotion, but to shew her Charms, and throw her Darts amongst the gazing Crowd, and grows more vain by Conquest I'm near the Church, and must step in, though it cost me a new Wound.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am resolv'd— Well, dear Charles, let's sup together to night, and contrive some way to be reveng'd of this wicked Uncle of mine. I must leave thee now, for I have an assignation here at Church.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Hah! at Church!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Aye, Charles, with the dearest she-Saint, and I hope sinner.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: What at Church? Pox, I shall be discovered now in my Amours. That's an odde place for Love-Intrigues.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh, I am to pass for a sober discreet person to the Relations; but for my Mistriss, she's made of no such sanctified Materials; she is a Widow, Charles, young, rich, and beautiful.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Hah! if this should prove my Widow now!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And though at her own dispose, yet is much govern'd by Honour, and a rigid Mother, who is ever preaching to her against the Vices of Youth, and t'other end of the Town Sparks; dreads nothing so much as her Daughters marrying a villanous Tory: So the young one is forc'd to dissemble Religion, the best Mask to hide a kind Mistriss in.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: This must be my Lady Galliard.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: There is at present some ill understanding between us; some damn'd Honourable Fop lays siege to her, which has made me ill received; and I having a new Intrigue elsewhere, return her cold disdain, but now and then she crosses my Heart too violently to resist her. In one of these hot fits I now am, and must find some occasion to speak to her.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: By Heaven, it must be she!— I am studying now, amongst all our she-Acquaintance, who this shou'd be.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh, this is of quality to be conceal'd: but the dearest loveliest Hypocrite, white as Lillies, smooth as Rushes, and plump as Grapes after showers, haughty her Meen, her Eyes full of disdain, and yet bewitching sweet; but when she loves, soft, witty, wanton, all that charms a Soul, and but for now and then a fit of Honour! Oh, damn the Nonsence, wou'd be all my own.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: 'Tis she, by Heaven! [aside.] Methinks this Widow shou'd prove a good Fortune to you, as things now stand between you and your▪ Uncle.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ah, Charles, but I am otherways dispos'd of. There is the most charming young thing in nature fallen in love with this person of mine, a rich City-Heiress, Charles; I have her in possession.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p:
How can you love two at once? I've been as wild, and as extravagant,
as Youth and Wealth cou'd render me; but ne'er arriv'd to that degree of Lewdness, to deal my Heart about: my Hours I might, but Love should be intire.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ah, Charles, two such bewitching Faces wou'd give thy Heart the lye:— But Love divides us, and I must into Church. Adieu till night.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: And I must follow to resolve my heart in what it dreads to learn. Here, my Cloak. [Takes his Cloak from his man, and puts it on.] Hah, Church is done! See, they are coming forth! Enter People cross the Stage, as from Church; amongst 'em Sir Anthony Meriwill, follow'd by Sir Tim. Treat-all. Hah, my Uncle! He must not see me here.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What my old Friend and Acquaintance, Sir Anthony Meriwill!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sir Timothy Treat-all!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Whe! How long have you been in Town, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: About three days, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Three days, and never came to dine with me! 'tis unpardonable! What, you keep close to the Church, I see: You are for the Surplice still▪ old Orthodox you: the Times cannot mend you, I see.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: No, nor shall they mar me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: They are discoursing; I'll pass by.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: As I take it, you came from Church too.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Aye, needs must, when the Devil drives. I go to save my Bacon, as they say, once a month, and that too, after the Porrage is serv'd up.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Those that made it, Sir, are wiser than we. For my part, I love good wholsome Doctrine, that teaches Obedience to my King and Superiours, without railing at the Government, and quoting Scripture for Sedition, Mutiny, and Rebellion. Why here was a jolly Fellow this morning made a notable Sermon. By George, our Country-Vicars are meer Scholars to your Gentlemen Town-Parsons! Hah, how he handled the Text, and run Divisions upon't! 'twou'd make a man sin with moderation, to hear how he claw'd away the Vices of the Town, Whoring, Drinking, and Conventicling, with the rest of the deadly number.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Good lack! an he were so good at Whoring and Drinking, you'd best carry your Nephew, Sir Charles Meriwill, to Church; he wants a little Documentizing that way.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Hum! You keep your old wont still; a man can begin no discourse to you, be it of Prester Iohn, but you still conclude with my Nephew.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Good Lord! Sir Anthony, you need not be so purty; what I say, is the Discourse of the whole City, how lavishly you let him live, and give ill Examples to all young Heirs.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: The City! the City's a grumbling, lying, dissatisfi'd City, and no wise or honest man regards what it says. Do you, or any of the City, stand bound to his Scrivener or Taylor? He spends what I allow him, Sir, his own; and you're a Fool or Knave, chuse ye whether, to concern your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Good lack! I speak but what wiser men discourse.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p:
Wiser men! wiser Coxcombs. What, they wou'd have me train my Nephew up, a hopeful Youth, to keep a Merchants Book, or send him to chop Logick in a University, and have him return an errant learned Ass, to simper, and look demure,
and start at Oaths and Wenches, whilst I fell his Woods, and grant Leases; and lastly, to make good what I have cozen'd him of, force him to marry Mrs. Crump, the ill-favour'd Daughter of some Right Worshipful.— A Pox of all such Guardians.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Do, countenance Sin and Expences, do.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What sin, what expences? He wears good Cloaths, why Trades-men get the more-by him; he keeps his Coach, 'tis for his ease; a Mistriss, 'tis for his pleasure; he games, 'tis for his diversion: And where's the harm of this? is there ought else you can accuse him with?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes;— a Pox upon him, he's my Rival too. [aside.] Why then I'll tell you, Sir, he loves a Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: If that be a sin, Heaven help the Wicked!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: But I mean honourably.—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Honourably! Why do you know any Infirmity in him, why he shou'd not marry?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Not you, Sir? why then you're an Ass, Sir.— But is the Lady young and handsome?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: A●e, and rich too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: No matter for Money, so she love the Boy.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Love him! no, Sir, she neither does, nor shall love him.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: How, Sir, nor shall love him! By George, but she shall, and lie with him too, if I please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, Sir! lie with a rich City-widow, and a Lady, and to be married to a fine Reverend old Gentleman within a day or two?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: His name, Sir, his name; I'll dispatch him presently.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, Sir, dispatch him!— Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Hold, Sir! by this abrupt departure, I fancy you the Boy's Rival: Come, draw.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, draw, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Aye draw, Sir: Not my Nephew have the Widow!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: With all my soul, Sir; I love and honour your Nephew. I his Rival! alas, Sir, I'm not so fond of Cuckoldom. Pray, Sir, let me see you and Sir Charles at my house, I may serve him in this business: and so I take my leave, Sir.— Draw quoth a! a Pox upon him for an old Tory-rory.

div.stage: Enter as from Church, Lady Galliard, Closet, and Footman: Wilding passes earelesly by her, Sir Charles Meriwill following wrapt in his Cloak.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Who's here? Charles muffled in a Cloak, peering after a woman?— My own Boy to a hair. She's handsome too. I'll step aside: for I must see the meaning on't.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Bless me! how unconcern'd he pass'd!

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: He bow'd low, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: But 'twas in such a fashion, as exprest Indifferency, much worse than Hate from Wilding.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Your Ladyship has us'd him ill of late; yet if your Ladyship please, I'll call him back.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: I'll die first.— Hah, he's going!— Yet now I think on't, I have a Toy of his, which to express my scorn, I'll give him back now:— this Ring.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Shall I carry it, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: You'll not express disdain enough in the delivery; and you may call him back.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: By Heaven, she's fond of him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh, Mrs. Closet! is it you?— Madam, your Servant: By this disdain, I fear your Woman, Madam, has mistaken her Man. Wou'd your Ladyship speak with me?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Yes.— But what? the God of Love instruct me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Command me quickly, Madam: for I have business.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Nay, then I cannot be discreet in Love.
— Your business once was Love, nor had no idle hours
To throw away on any other thought.
You lov'd as if you'd had no other Faculties,
As if you'd meant to gain Eternal Bliss
By that Devotion onely: And see how now you're chang'd.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Not I, by Heaven; 'tis you are onely chang'd.
I thought you'd love me too, curse on the dull mistake;
But when I beg'd to reap the mighty Joy
That Mutual Love affords,
You turn'd me off for Honour,
That nothing fram'd by some old sullen Maid,
That wanted Charms to kindle flames when young.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: By George, he's i'th' right.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Death! can she hear this Language?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: How dare you name this to me any more?
Have you forgot my Fortune, and my Youth?
My Quality, and Fame?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: No, by Heaven, all these increase my Flame.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Perhaps they might, but yet I wonder where
You got the boldness to approach me with it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Faith, Madam, from your own encouragement.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: From mine! Heavens, what contempt is this!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: When first I paid my Vows, (good Heaven forgive me)
They were for Honour all;
But wiser you, thanks to your Mothers care too,
Knowing my Fortune an uncertain hope,
My Life of scandal, and my lewd Opinion,
Forbid my Wish that way: 'Twas kindly urg'd;
You cou'd not then forbid my Passion too,
Nor did I ever from your Lips or Eyes,
Receive the cruel sentence of my Death.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Gad, a fine fellow this!

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: To save my life, I wou'd not marry thee.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: That's kindly said:
But to save mine, thou't do a kinder thing;
— I know thou wo't.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: What, yield my Honour up!
And after find it sacrific'd anew,
And made the scorn of a triumphing Wife!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Gad, she's i'th' right too; a noble Girl I'll warrant her.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: But you disdain to satisfie those fears;
And like a proud and haughty Conqueror,
Demand the Town, without the least Conditions.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: By Heaven, she yields apace.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Pox on't, wou'd I'd ne'er seen her; now have I a Legend of small Cupids at Hot-cockles in my heart.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Now am I pawsing on that word Conditions.
Thou sayst thou wou'dst not have me marry thee;
That is, as if I lov'd thee for thy Eyes,
And put 'em out to hate thee:
sp.p: Or like our Stage-smitten Youth, who fall in love with a woman for-Acting finely, and by taking her off the Stage, deprive her of the onely Charm she had,
sp.l: Then leave her to Ill Luck.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Gad, he's i'th' right again too! A rare Fellow!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: For, Widow, know, hadst thou more Beauty, yet not all of 'em were half so great a Charm as thy not being mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Hum! How will he make that out now?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: The stealths of Love, the Midnight kind admittance,
The gloomy Bed, the soft-breath'd murmuring Passion;
Ah, who can guess at Joys thus snatcht by parcels!
The difficulty makes us always wishing,
Whilst on thy part, Fear still makes some resistance;
And every Blessing seems a kind of Rape.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: H'as don't!— A Divine Fellow this; just of my Religion. I am studying now whether I was never acquainted with his Mother.

div.stage: L. Gall. walks away, Wild. follows.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Tempt me no more! What dull unwary Flame
Possest me all this while! Confusion on thee,
And all the Charms that dwell upon thy Tongue.
Diseases ruine that bewitching form,
That with thy soft feign'd Vows debaucht my Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Heavens! can I yet endure!

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: By all that's good, I'll marry instantly;
Marry, and save my last stake, Honour, yet,
Or thou wilt rook me out of all at last.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Marry! thou canst not do a better thing:
There are a thousand Matrimonial Fops,
Fine Fools of Fortune,
Good-natur'd Blockheads too, and that's a wonder.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: That will be manag'd by a man of Wit..

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I have an eye upon a Friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: A Friend of mine! then he must be my Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Very fine! can I endure yet more?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Perhaps it is your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Hah, my Uncle!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Hah, my Charles! why well said Charles, he bore up briskly to her.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, may I presume to tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Ah, Pox, that was stark naught! he begins like a Fore-man of th' Shop▪ to his Masters Daughter.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How, Charles Meriwill acquainted with my Widow!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Why do you wear that scorn upon your face?
I've nought but honest meaning in my Passion;
Whilst him you favour, so prophanes your Beauties,
In scorn of Marriage and religious Rites,
Attempts the ruine of your sacred Honour.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hah, Wilding, boast my love!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: The Devil take him, my Nephew's quite spoil'd!
Why what a Pox has he to do with Honour now?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Pray leave me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Damn it, since he knows all, I'll boldly own my flame—
You take a liberty I never gave you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: How, this from thee! nay, then I must take more,
And ask you where you borrow'd that Brutality,
T'approach that Lady with your sawcy Passion.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Gad, well done, Charles! here must be sport anon.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I will not answer every idle Question.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Death, you dare not.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How, dare not!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: No, dare not: for if you did—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What durst you, if I did?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Death, cut your Throat, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Hold, hold, let him have fair play, and then curse him that parts ye.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hold, I command ye, hold!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: There rest my Sword to all Eternity.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Now I conjure ye both, by all your Honour,
If you were e'er acquainted with that Vertue,
To see my face no more,
Who durst dispute your interest in me thus,
As for a common Mistriss, in your Drink.

div.stage: She goes out, and all but Wild. Sir Anth. and Sir Char. who stands sadly looking after her.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: A heavenly Girl!— Well, now she's gone, by George, I am for disputing your Title to her by dint of Sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I wo'not fight.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Another time we will decide it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: After your whining Prologue, Sir, who the Devil would have expected such a Farce?— Come, Charles, take up thy Sword, Charles;— and, d'ye hear, forget me this Woman.—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Forget her, Sir! there never was a thing so excellent!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: You lye, Sirrah, you lye, there are a thousand
As fair, as young, and kinder, by this day.
We'll into th' Country, Charles, where every Grove
Affords us Rustick Beauties,
That know no Pride nor Painting,
And that will take it and be thankful, Charles;
Fine wholsome Girls that fall like ruddy Fruit,
Fit for the gathering, Charles.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Oh, Sir, I cannot relish the coarse Fare.
But what's all this, Sir, to my present Passion?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Passion, Sir! you shall have no Passion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: No Passion, Sir! shall I have life and breath?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: It may be not, Sirrah, if it be my will and pleasure.
— Why how now! sawcy Boys be their own Carvers?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Sir, I am all Obedience.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Obedience! Was ever such a Blockhead! Why then if I command it, you will not love this Woman?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: No, Sir! But I say, Yes, Sir, love her me; and love her me like a man too, or I'll renounce ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: I've try'd all ways to win upon her heart,
Presented, writ, watcht, fought, pray'd, kneel'd, and weept.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Why there's it now; I thought so: Kneel'd and weept! a Pox upon thee— I took thee for a prettier fellow.—
sp.l: You shou'd a hufft and bluster'd at her door;
Been very impudent and sawcy, Sir;
Lewd, ruffling, mad; courted at all hours and seasons;
Let her not rest, nor eat, nor sleep, nor visit.
Believe me, Charles, women love importunity.
Watch her close, watch her like a Witch, Boy,
Till she confess the Devil in her,— Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: I cannot, Sir.
Her Eyes strike such an awe into my Soul,—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Strike such a Fiddlestick.— Sirrah, I say, do't; what, you can towse a Wench as handsomly— You can be lewd enough upon occasion. I know not the Lady, nor her Fortune; but I am resolv'd thou shalt have her, with practising a little Courtship of my mode.— Come—
sp.l: Come my Boy Charles, since you must needs be doing,
I'll shew thee how to go a Widow-wooing.

div.head: SCENE the First. A Room.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: ENough, I've heard enough of Wilding's Vices, to know I am undone. [weeps]— Galliard his Mistriss too? I never saw her, but I have heard her fam'd for Beauty, Wit, and Fortune.
sp.l: That Rival may be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, the fair, the young, the witty Lady Galliard, even in the height of all his love to you; nay, even whilst his Uncle courts her for a Wife, he designes himself for a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Wonderous Inconstancy and Impudence!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, you may rely upon Mr. Fopington's Information: therefore if you respect your Reputation, retreat in time.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Reputation! that I forfeited when I ran away with your Friend Mr. Wilding.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Ah, that ever I should live to see [weeps] the sole Daughter and Heir of Sir Nicholas Gettall, run away with one of the lewdest Heathens about town!

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: How! your Friend Mr. Wilding a Heathen; and with you too, Mrs. Clacket! That Friend Mr. Wilding, who thought none so worthy as Mrs. Clacket, to trust with so great a secret as his flight with me; he a Heathen!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Aye, and a poor Heathen too, Madam. 'Slife, if you must marry a man to buy him Breeches, marry an honest man, a religious man, a man that bears a Conscience, and will do a woman some Reason.— Why here's Mr. Fopington, Madam; here's a Shape, here's a Face, a Back as straight as an Arrow, I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: How! buy him Breeches! Has Wilding then no Fortune?

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Yes, Faith, Madam, pretty well; so, so, as the Dice run: and now and then he lights upon a Squire, or so, and between fair and foul Play, he makes a shift to pick a pretty Livelihood up.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: How! does his Uncle allow him no present Maintenance?

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: No, nor future Hopes neither: Therefore, Madam, I hope you will see the difference between him and a man of Parts, that adores you.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: If I find all this true you tell me, I shall know how to value my self and those that love me.
sp.l: — This may be yet a Rascal.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Mistriss, Mr. Wilding's below.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Below! Oh, Heavens, Madam, do not expose me to his lewd fury, for being too zealous in your service.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: I will not let him know you told any thing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Death! to be seen here, would expose my Life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Here, here, step out upon the Sair-case, and slip into my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: ‛ Owns, he's here! lock the door fast; let him not enter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens, I have not the Key! hold it, hold it fast, sweet, sweet Mr. Foping Oh, should there be Murder done, what a scandal wou'd that be to the house of a true Protestant!

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Heavens! what will he say and think, to see me shut in with a man?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Oh, I'll say you're sick, asleep, or out of humour.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: I'd give the world to see him. [Knocks.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: [Without.] Charlot, Charlot! Am I deny'd an entrance? By Heaven, I'll break the door.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Oh, I'm a dead man, dear Clacket!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Oh, hold, Sir, Mrs. Charlot is very sick.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How, sick, and I kept from her!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: She begs you'll come again an hour hence.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Delay'd, by Heaven I will have enterance.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Ruin'd! undone! for if he do not kill me, he may starve me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Oh, he will break in upon us! Hold, Sir, hold a little; Mrs. Charlot is just-just-shifting her self, Sir: you will not be so uncivil as to press in, I hope, at such a time.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: I have a fine time on't between ye, to have him think I am stripping my self before Mr. Fopington— Let go, or I'll call out and tell him all.

div.stage: Wild. breaks open the door and rushes in: Fop. stands close up at the enterance till he is past him, then venturing to slip out, finds Wild. has made fast the door; so he is forc'd to return again and stand close up behind Wild. with signs of fear.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How now, Charlot, what means this new unkindness? What, not a word?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: There is so little Musick in my Voice, you do not care to hear it; you have been better entertain'd, I find, mightily employ'd, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes Faith, and so I have, Charlot: Damn'd Business, that Enemy to Love, has made me rude.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Or that other Enemy to Love, damn'd Wenching.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Wenching! how ill hast thou tim'd thy Jealousie!
What Banker, that to morrow is to pay a mighty sum, wou'd venture out his stock to day in little parcels, and lose his Credit by it?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: You wou'd, perfidious as you are, though all your Fortune, all your future Health, depended on that Credit.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So: Heark ye, Mrs. Clacket, you have been prating I find in my absence, giving me a handsome character to Charlot.— You hate any good thing should go by your own Nose.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: By my Nose, Mr. Wilding! I defie you: I'd have you to know, I scorn any good thing shou'd go by my Nose in an uncivil way.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p:
Have I been the Confident to all your secrets this three years, in sickness and in health, for richer, for poorer; concealed the nature of your wicked Diseases, under the honest name of Surfeits; call'd your filthy Surgeons▪ Mr. Doctor,
to keep up your Reputation; civily receiv'd your tother end of the● Town young Relations at all hours;—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: High!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Been up with you and down with you early and late, by night and by day; let you in at all hours, drunk and sober, single and double, and civilly withdrawn, and modestly shut the door after me?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Whir! The storm's up, and the Devil cannot lay it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: And am I thus rewarded for my pain!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So Tempests are allay'd by showers of Rain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: That I shou'd be charg'd with speaking ill of you, so honest, so civil a Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: No, I have better witness of your falshood.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Hah, 'sdeath, she'll name me!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What mean you, my Charlot?
Do you not think I love you?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Go ask my Lady Galliard, she keeps the best account of all your Sighs and Vows,
sp.l: And robs me of my dearest softer hours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: You cannot hold from being kind to him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Galliard! How came she by that secret of my life? [aside.] Why Aye, 'tis true, I am there sometimes about an Arbitration, about a Suit in Law, about my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Aye, that Uncle too—
You swore to me you were your Uncles Heir;
But you perhaps may chance to get him one,
If the Lady prove not cruel.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Death and the Devil, what Rascal has been prating to her!

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Whilst I am reserv'd for a dead lift, if Fortune prove unkind, or wicked Uncles refractory,
sp.l: Yet I cou'd love you, though you were a Slave,
And I were Queen of all the Universe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.l: Aye, there you spoil'd all again— you forget your self.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: And all the world, when he looks kindly on me.
But I'll take courage, and be very angry.
sp.p: Nor does your Perjuries rest here; you're equally as false to Galliard, as to me; false for a little Mistriss of the Town, whom you've set up in spight to Quality.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.l: So, that was home and handsome.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What damn'd Informer does she keep in Pension?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: And can you think my Fortune and my Youth
Merits no better Treatment?
How cou'd you have the heart to use me so?
I fall insensibly to Love and Fondness.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Charlot! you who know my heart, can you believe me false?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: In every Syllable, in every Look:
Your Vows, your Sighs, and Eyes, all counterfeit;
You said you lov'd me, where was then your truth?
You swore you were to be your Uncle's Heir:
Where was your confidence of me the while,
To think my Generosity so scanted,
To love you for your Fortune?
— How every look betrays my yielding heart!
No, since men are grown so cunning in their
Trade of Love, the necessary Vice I'll practice too▪
And chaffer with Love-Merchants for my Heart.
Make it appear you are your Uncles Heir,
I'll marry ye tomorrow.
Of all thy Cheats, that was the most unkind,
Because you thought to conquer by that Lye.
— To night I'll be resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Hum! to night!

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: To night, or I will think you love me for my Fortune; which if you find elsewhere to more advantage,
sp.l: I may unpitied die— and I should die,
If you should prove untrue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.l: There you've dasht all again.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I am resolv'd to keep my credit with her▪— Here's my hand:
This night, Charlot, I'll let you see the Writings.
— But how, a Pox of him that knows for Thomas.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Hah, that Hand without the Ring!
Nay, never study for a handsome Lye.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Ring! Oh, aye, I left it in my Dressing-room this morning.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: See how thou hast inur'd thy Tongue to Falshood!
Did you not send it to a certain Creature
They call Diana,
From off that hand that plighted Faith to me?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: By Heaven, 'tis Witchcraft all,
Unless this Villain Fopington betray me.
Those sort of Rascals will do any thing
For ready Meat and Wine.— I'll kill the Fool— Hah, here!

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.l: Here, Lord! Lord!
sp.stage: [Turns quick and sees him behind him.
sp.l: Where were thy Eyes, dear Wilding?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Where they have spy'd a Rascal.
Where was this Property conceal'd?

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Conceal'd! What dost thou mean, dear Tom? Why I stood as plain as the Nose on thy Face, mun.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: But 'tis the ungrateful quality of all your sort, to make such base returns.
How got this Rogue admittance, and when in,
The Impudence to tell his treacherous Lyes?

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Admittance! Why thou'rt stark mad: Did not I come in with you, that is, followed you?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Why into the house, up stairs, stood behind you when you swore you wou'd come in, and followed you in.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: All this, and I not see!

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Oh, Love's blind; but this Lady saw me, Mrs. Clacket saw 〈◊〉— Admittance quotha!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why did you not speak?

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Speak! I was so amaz'd at what I heard, the villanous Scandals laid on you by some pick-thank Rogue or other, I had no power.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Aye, thou knowst how I am wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Oh, most damnably, Sir!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Abuse me to my Mistriss too!

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Oh, Villains! Dogs!

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Do you think they've wrong'd him, Sir? for I'll believe you.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Do I think, Madam? Aye, I think him a Son of a Whore that said it; and I'll cut's Throat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.l: Well, this Impudence is a heavenly Vertue!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You see now, Madam, how Innocence may suffer.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: In spight of all thy villanous dissembling,
I must believe, and love thee for my quiet.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That's kind; and if before to morrow I do not shew you I deserve your Heart, kill me at once by quitting me.— Farewel.— [goes out with Fop.] I know both where my Uncle's Will and other Writings lie, by which he made me Heir to his whole Estate.
sp.l: My craft will be in catching; which if past,
Her Love secures me the kind Wench at last.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: What if he shou'd not chance to keep his word now?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: How if he shou'd not? by all that's good, if he shou'd not, I am resolv'd to marry him however. We two may make a pretty shift with three thousand pound a year: yet I would fain be resolv'd how affairs stand between the old Gentleman and him. I wou'd give the world to see that Widow too, that Lady Galliard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: If you're bent upon't▪ I'll tell you what we'll do, Madam: There's every day mighty Feasting here at his Uncles hard by, and you shall disguise your self as well as you can, and go for a Niece of mine I have coming out of Scotland: where you will not fail of seeing my Lady Galliard, though I doubt, not Mr. Wilding, who is of late discarded.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Enough; I am resolv'd upon this designe: Let's in and and practise the Northern Dialect.

div.head: SCENE the Second. The Street.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But then Diana took the Ring at last?

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Greedl●y; but rail'd, and swore, ● and ranted at your late unkindness, and wou'd not be appeas'd.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Dresswell, I was just going to see for thee.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: I'm glad, dear Tom, I'm here to serve thee.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And now I've found thee, thou must along with me.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Whither? But I'll not ask, but obey.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: To a kind sinner, Frank.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Pox on 'em all: prithee turn out those petty Tyrants of thy Heart, and fit it for a Monarch, Love, dear Widling, of which thou never knewst the pleasure yet, or not above a day.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Not knew the pleasure! Death, the very Essence, the first draughts of Love:
sp.l: Ah, how pleas●●●● is to drink when a man's adry!
The rest is all but dully ●ipping on.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: And yet this Diana, for thither thou art going, thou hast been constant to this three or four years.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A constant Keeper thou meanst; which is indeed enough to get the scandal of a Coxcomb: But I know not, those sort of Baggages have a kind of Fascination so inticing— and Faith, after the Fatigues of Formal Visits to a mans dull Relations, or what's as bad, to women of Quality; after the busie Afflictions of the Day, and the Debauches of the tedious Night, I tell thee, Frank, a man's best Retirement is with a soft kind Wench. But to say truth, I have a farther designe in my Visit▪ now. Thou knowst how I stand past hope of Grace, excommunicated the Kindness of my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: My lewd Debauches, and being o'th wrong Party, as he calls it, is now become an reconcilable Quarrel; so that I having many and hopeful Intrigues now depending, especially these of my charming Widow, and my City-Heiress, which can by no means be carri'd on without that damn'd Necessary call'd Ready Money, I have stretcht my Credit, as all young Heirs do, till 'tis quite broke. Now Liveries, Coaches, and Cloaths must be had, they must, my Friend.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Why dost thou not in this Extremity clap up a Match with my Lady Galliard? or this young Heiress you speak of?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But Marriage, Frank, is such a Bug-bear! And this old Uncle of mine may one day be gathered together, and sleep with his Fathers, and then I shall have six thousand pound a year, and the wide World before me; and who the Devil cou'd relish these Blessings with the clog of a Wife behind him?— But till then, Money must be had, I say.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Aye, but how, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why, from the old Fountain, Iack, my Uncle; he has himself decreed it: he tells me I must live upon my Wits, and will, Frank.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Gad, I'm impatient to know how.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I believe thee, for thou art out at Elboes: and when I thrive, you show i'●h' Pit, behind the Scenes, and Coffee-houses. Thy Breeches give a better account of my Fortune, than Lilly with all his Schemes and Stars.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: I own I thrive by your Influence, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Well; but to your Project, Friend: to which I'll set a helping Hand, a Heart, a Sword, and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You make good what my Soul conceives of you. Let's to Diana then, and there I'll tell thee all. [Going out, they meet Diana, who enters with her Maid Betty, and Boy; looks angrily.— Diana, I was just going to thy Lodgings!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Oh las, you are too much taken up with your rich City-Heiress.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That's no cause of quarrel between you and I, Diana; you were wont to be as impatient for my marrying, as I for the death of my Uncle: for your rich Wife ever obliges her Husbands Mistriss; and women of your sort, Diana, ever thrive better by Adultery than Fornication.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Do, try to appease the easie Fool with these fine Expectations:— No, I have been too often flatter'd with the hopes of your marrying a rich Wife, and then I was to have a Settlement; but instead of that, things go backward with me, my Coach is vanisht, my Servants dwindled into one necessary Woman and a Boy, which to save Charges, is too small for any service; my twenty Guinnies a week, into forty Shillings: a hopeful Reformation!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Patience, Diana, things will mend in time.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: When, I wonder? Summer's come, yet I am still in my embroider'd Manto, when I'm drest, lin'd with Velvet; 'twou'd give one a Feavor but to look at me: yet still I am flamm'd off with hopes of a rich Wife, whose Fortune I am to lavish.— But I see you have neither Conscience nor Religion in you; I wonder what a Devil will become of your Soul for thus deluding me!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By Heaven, I love thee!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Love me! what if you do? how far will that go at the Exchange for Poynt? Will the Mercer take it for currant Coin?— But 'tis no matter, I must love a Wit, with a Pox, when I might have had so many Fools of Fortune: But the Devil take me, if you deceive me any longer.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You'll keep your word, no doubt, now you have sworn.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: So I will. I never go abroad, but I gain new Conquest. Happy's the man that can approach neerest the side-box where I sit at a Play, to look at me; but if I daign to smile on him, Lord, how the o're-joy'd Creature returns it with a bow low as the very Benches! Then rising, shakes his Ears, looks round, with pride, to see who took notice how much he was in favour with charming Mrs. Dy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No more: Come, let's be Friends, Diana; for you and I must manage an Uncle of mine.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Damn your Projects, I'll have none of 'em.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Here, here's the best Softner of a womans heart; 'tis told, two hundred Pieces: Go, lay it on, till you shame Quality, into plain Silk and Fringe.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Lord, you have the strangest power of Perswasion!— Nay, if you buy my Peace, I can afford a penyworth.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So thou canst of any thing about thee.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Well, your Project, my dear Tommy?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Thus then— Thou, dear Frank, shalt to my Uncle, O tell him that Sir Nicholas Gettall, as he knows, being dead, and having left, as he knows too, one onely Daughter his whole Executrix, Mrs. Charlot, I have by my civil and modest behaviour, so won upon her heart, that two nights since she left her Fathers Country-house at Lusum in Kent, in spight of all her strict Guards, and run away with me.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: How, wilt thou tell him of it then?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Hear me— That I have hitherto secured her at a Friends house here in the City; but diligent search being now made, dare trust her there no longer. And make it my humble Request by you, my Friend, (who are onely privy to this secret) that he wou'd give me leave to bring her home to his house; whose very Authority will defend her from being fought for there.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, but what will come of this, I say?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why a Settlement: You know he has already made me Heir to all he has, after his decease; but for being a wicked Tory, as he calls me, he has, after the Writings were made, sign'd, and seal'd, refus'd to give 'em in trust. Now when he secs I have made my self Master of so vast a Fortune, he will immediately surrender, that reconciles all again.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Very likely; but wo't thou trust him with the woman, Thomas?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No; here's Diana, who as I shall bedizen, shall pass for as substantial an Aldermans Heiress, as ever fell into wicked hands. He never knew the right Charlot, nor indeed has any body ever seen her but an old Aunt and Nurse, she was so kept up:— And there, Diana, thou shalt have a good opportunity to lye▪ dissemble, and jilt in abundance, to keep thy hand in ure.
sp.l: Prithee, dear Dresswell, haste with the News to him.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Faith, I like this well enough; this Project may take, and I'll about it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Go, get ye home, and trick and betawder your self up like a right City-Lady, rich, but ill-fashion'd; on with all your Jewels, but not a Patch, ye Gipsie, nor no Spanish Paint, d'ye hear.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: I'll warrant you for my part.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Then before the old Gentleman, you must behave your self very soberly, simple, and demure, and look as prew as at a Conventicle; and take heed you drink not off your Glass at Table, nor rant, nor swear; one Oath confounds our Plot, and betrays thee to be an errant Drab.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Doubt not my Art of Dissimulation.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Go, haste and dress—

div.stage: Enter L. Gall. and Closet above in the Balconey; Wild. going out, sees them, stops, and reads a Paper.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Hah, who's yonder, the Widow! a Pox upon't, now have not I power to stir: she has a damn'd ●ank upon my Heart, and nothing but right down lying with her, will dissolve the Charm. She has forbid me seeing her, and therefore I am sure will the sooner take notice of me.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: What will you put on to night, Madam? you know you are to sup at Sir Timothy Treat-all's.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Time enough for that; prithee let's take a turn in this Balconey, this City-garden, where we walk to take the fresh Air of the Sea-coal-smoak. Did the Footman go back, as I order'd him, to see how Wilding and Sir Charles parted?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: He did, Madam; and nothing cou'd provoke Sir Charles to fight after your Ladyships strict Commands. Well, I'll swear he's the sweetest natur'd Gentleman— was all the advantages of Nature and Fortune: I wonder what Exception your Ladyship has to him▪

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Some small Exception to his whining humour; but I think my chiefest dislike is, because my Relations wish it a Match between us.
It is not hate to him, but natural contradiction. Hah, is not that Wilding yonder? he's reading of a Letter sure.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So, she sees me. Now for an Art to make her lure me up: for though I have a greater mind than she, it shall be all her own; the Match she told me of this morning with my Uncle, sticks plaguily upon my stomach; I must break the neck on't, or break the Widows heart, that's certain. If I advance towards the door now, she frowningly retires; if I pass on, 'tis likely she may call me.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I think he's passing on,
Without so much as looking towards the window.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: He's glad of the excuse of being forbidden.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: But, Closet, knowest thou not he has abus'd my fame,
And does he think to pass thus unupbraided?
Is there no Art to make him look this way?
No trick?— Prithee faign to laugh.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: So, I shall not answer to that Call.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: He's going! Ah, Closet, my Fan!— [Lets fall her Fan just as he passes by; he takes it up, and looks up.] Cry mercy, Sir, I'm sorry I must trouble you to bring it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith, so am I; and you may spare my pains, and send your Woman for't, I am in haste.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Then the quickest way will be to bring it.

div.stage: Goes out of the Belconey with Closet.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I knew I should be drawn in one way or other.

div.stage: Enter L. Gall. Closet to them; Wilding delivers the Fan, and is retiring.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Stay; I hear you're wonderous free of your Tongue, when 'tis let loose on me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Who I, Widow? I think of no such trifles.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Such Railers never think when they're abusive; but something you have said, a Lye so infamous!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: A Lye, and infamous of you! impossible!
What was it that I call'd you, Wise, or Honest?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: How, can you accuse me for the want of either?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes, of both: Had you a grain of Honesty, or intended ever to be thought so, wou'd you have the impudence to marry an old Coxcomb, a Fellow that will not so much as serve you for a Cloak, he is so visibly and undeniably impotent?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Your Uncle you mean.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I do; who has not known the joy of Fornication this thirty year, and now the Devil and you have put it into his head to marry, forsooth. Oh the Felicity of the Wedding-night!

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Which you, with all your railing Rhetorick, shall not have power to hinder.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Not if you can help it: for I perceive you are resolv'd to be a lewd incorrigible sinner, and marryest this seditious doting fool my Uncle, onely to hang him out for the signe of the Cuckold, to give notice where Beauty is to be purchas'd, for fear otherwise we should mistake, and think thee honest.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: So much for my want of Honesty; my Wit is the Part of the Text you are to handle next.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Let the World judge of that, by this one action: This Marriage undisputably robs you both of your Reputation and Pleasure. Marry an old Fool, because he's rich! when so many handsome proper younger Brothers wou'd be glad of you!

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Of which hopeful number your self are one.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Who, I! Bear witness, Closet; take notice I'm upon my Marriage, Widow, and such a Scandal on my Reputation might ruine me: therefore have a care what you say.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Marriage! Yes, I hear you give it out, you are to be married to me: for which Defamation, if I be not reveng'd, hang me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes, you are reveng'd: I had the fame of vanquishing where-e're I laid my Siege, till I knew thee, hard-hearted thee; had the honest Reputation of lying with the Magistrates Wives, when their Reverend Husbands were employ'd in the necessary Affairs of the Nation, seditiously petitioning; and then I was esteemed; but now they look on me as a monsterous thing, that makes honourable Love to you; Oh hideous, a Husband-Lover! So that now I may protest, and swear, and lye my heart out, I find neither Credit nor Kindness; but when I beg for either, my Lady Galliard's thrown in my Dish: Then they laugh aloud, and cry, Who would think it of gay, of fine Mr. Wilding! Thus the City She-wits are let loose upon me, and all for you, sweet Widow; but I am resolved I will redeem my Reputation again, if never seeing you nor writing to you more, will do it: And so farewel, faithless and scandalous honest woman▪

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Stay, Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am engag'd.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: You are not.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am, and am resolv'd to lose no more time on a peevish woman, who values her Honour above her Lover.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Go; this is the noblest way of losing thee.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Must not I call him back?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: No: If any honest Lover come, admit him; I will forget this Devil. Fetch me some Jewels; the company to night at Sir Timothy's may divert me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Madam, one Sir Anthony Meriwill wou'd speak with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Admit him; sure 'tis Sir Charles his Uncle: if he come to treat a Match with me for his Nephew, he takes me in the critical minute. Wou'd he but leave his whining, I might love him, if 'twere but in revenge.

div.stage: Enter Sir Anthony Meriwill and Sir Charles.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p:
So, I have tutor'd the young Rogue, I hope he'll learn in time. Good day to your Ladyship; Charles [putting him forward] my Nephew here, Madam—
Sirrah— notwithstanding your Ladyships Commands— Look how he stands now, being a mad young Raskal!— Gad, he wou'd wait on your Ladyship— A Devil on him, see if he'll budge now— For he's a brisk Lover, Madam, when he once begins. A Pox on him, he'll spoil all yet.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Please you sit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Madam, I beg your Pardon for my Rudeness.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Still whining?—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: D'ye hear that, Sirrah? Oh damn it, beg Pardon! The Rogue's quite out of 's part.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Madam, I fear my Visit is unseasonable.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Unseasonable! Damn'd Rogue, unseasonable to a Widow!— Quite out.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: There are indeed some Ladies that wou'd be angry at an untimely Visit, before they've put on their best Faces; but I am none of those that wou'd be fair in spight of Nature, Sir.— Put on this Jewel here.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: That Beauty needs no Ornament, Heaven has been too bountiful.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Heaven! Oh Lord, Heaven! a Puritanical Rogue, he courts her like her Chaplain.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: You are still so full of University-Complements—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: D'ye hear that, Sirrah?— Aye so he is, so he is indeed, Madam.— To her like a man, ye Knave.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, I am come!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: To shew your self a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: To tire me with discourses of your Passion.— Fie, how this Curl sits!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No, you shall hear no more of that ungrateful subject.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Son of a Whore, hear no more of Love, damn'd Rogue! Madam, by George he lyes; he does come to speak of Love, and make Love, and to do Love, and all for Love.— Not come to speak of Love, with a Pox! ' Owns, Sir, behave your self like a man; be impudent, be sawcy, forward, bold, towzing, and lewd, d'ye hear, or I'll beat thee before her. Why what a Pox!

div.stage: [Aside to him, he minds it not.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Finding my hopes quite lost in your unequal Favours to young Wilding, I'm quitting of the Town.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: You will do well to do so.— Lay by that Necklace; I'll wear Pearl to day.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Confounded Blockhead!— By George, he lyes again, Madam. A Dog, I'll dis-inherit him. [aside.] He quit the Town, Madam! no, not whilst your Ladyship is in it, to my knowledge. He'll live in the Town, nay, in the Street where you live; nay, in the House; nay, in the very Bed, by George; I've heard him a thousand times swear it. Swear it now, Sirrah: Look, look, how he stands now! Why dear Charles, good Boy, swear a little, ruffle her, and swear Damn it, she shall have none but thee. [aside to him.] Why you little think, Madam, that this Nephew of mine is one of the maddest Fellows in all Devonshire.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd see't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p:
See't! look ye there, ye Rogue.— Why 'tis all his fault, Madam. He's seldom sober; then he has a dozen Wenches in pay, that he may with the more Authority
break their widdows. There's never a Maid within forty miles of Meriwill-hall to work a Miracle on, but all are Mothers. He's a hopeful Youth, I'll say that for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How I have lov'd you, my despairs shall witness: for I will die to purchase your content.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Die, a damn'd Rogue! Aye, aye, I'll dis-inherit him: A Dog, die, with a Pox! No, he'll be hang'd first, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: And sure you'll pity me when I am dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: A Curse on him; pity, with a Pox! I'll give him ne'er a Souse.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Give me that Essence-bottle.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: But for a recompence of all my sufferings—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Sprinkle my Handkercher with Tuberuse.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I beg a Favour you'd afford a stranger.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Sooner perhaps. What Jewel's that?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: One Sir Charles Meriwill—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Sent, and you receiv'd without my order!
No wonder that he looks so scurvily.
Give him the Trifle back to mend his humour.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I thank you, Madam, for that repromand. Look in that Glass, Sir, and admire that sneaking Coxcomb's Countenance of yours: A Pox on him, he's past Grace, lost, gone, not a Souse, not a Groat; good buy to you, Sir. Madam, I beg your Pardon; the next time I come a wooing, it shall be for my self, Madam, and I have something that will justifie it too; but as for this fellow, if your Ladyship have e'er a small Page at leisure, I desire he may have order to kick him down stairs. Adamn'd Rogue, to be civil now, when he shou'd have behav'd himself handsomely! Not an Acre, not a Shilling,— buy, Sir Softhead. [going out, meets Wild. and returns.] Hah, who have we here, hum, the fine mad Fellow? So, so, he'll swindge him I hope; I'll stay to have the pleasure of seeing it done.

div.stage: Enter Wilding, brushes by Sir Charles.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I was sure 'twas Meriwill's Coach at door.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Hah, Wilding!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Aye, now Sir, here's one will waken ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How now, Widow, you are always giving Audience to Lovers, I see.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: You're very free, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'm always so in the widows Lodgings, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: A rare Fellow!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: You will not do't elsewhere?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Not with so much Authority.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: An admirable Fellow! I must be acquainted with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Is this the Respect you pay women of her Quality?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The Widow knows I stand not much on Ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Gad, he shall be my Heir. [Aside still.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Pardon him, Sir, this is his Cambridge-breeding.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Aye so 'tis, so 'tis; that two years there quite spoil'd him.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Sir, if you've any farther business with me, speak it; if not, I'm going forth.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Madam, in short—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: In short to a Widow, in short! quite lost.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: I find you treat me ill for my Respect;
And when I court you next,
I will forget how very much I love you.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sir, I shall be proud of your farther acquaintance; for I like, love, and honour you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll study to deserve it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Madam, your Servant. A damn'd sneaking Dog to be civil and modest, with a Pox!

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: See if my Coach be ready.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Whither are you janting now?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Where you dare not wait on me; to your Uncles to Supper.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: That Uncle of mine pimps for all the Sparks of his Party;
There they all meet and bargain without scandal:
Fops of all sorts and sizes you may chuse.
Whig-land affords not such another Market.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Madam, here's Sir Timothy Treat-all come to wait on your Ladyship to Supper.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: My Uncle! Oh, damn him, he was born to be my Plague: Not dis-inheriting me had been so great a disappointment; and if he sees me here, I ruine all the Plots I've laid for him. Had he's here!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: How, my Nephew Thomas here!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Madam, I find you can be cruel too,
Knowing my Uncle has abandon'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How now, Sir, what's your business here?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I came to beg a Favour of my Lady Galliard, Sir, knowing her Power and Quality here in the City.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, a Favour of my Lady Galliard! The Rogue said indeed he wou'd Cuckold me. [aside.] Why, Sir, I thought you had been taken up with your rich Heiress?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That was my business now, Sir: Having in my possession the Daughter and Heir of Sir Nicholas Gettall, I would have made use of the Authority of my Lady Galliard's house to have secur'd her, till I got things in order for our Marriage; but my Lady, to put me off, cryes, I have an Uncle.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: A well-contriv'd Lye.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, I have heard of your good Fortune; and however a Reprobate thou hast been, I'll not shew my self so undutiful an Uncle, as not to give the Gentlewoman a little house-room: I heard indeed she was gone a week ago,
sp.l: And, Sir, my house is at your service.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I humbly thank you, Sir. Madam, your Servant. A Pox upon him, and all his Association.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Come, Madam, my Coath waits below.

div.head: SCENE the First. A Room.
div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy Treat-all and Jervice.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: HEre, take my Sword, Iervice. What have you inquir'd as I directed you concerning the rich Heiress, Sir Nicholas Gettall's Daugher?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, inquir'd! why 'tis all the City-News, that she's run away with one of the maddest Tories about Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Good Lord! Aye, aye, 'tis so; the plaguie Rogue my Nephew has got her. That Heaven shou'd drop such Blessings in the mouths of the Wicked! Well' Iervice, what Company have we in the house, Iervice?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Why truely, Sir, a fine deal, considering there's no Parliament.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What Lords have we, Iervice?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Lords, Sir! truly none.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: None! what ne'er a Lord! Some mishap will befal me, some dire mischance: Ne'er a Lord! ominous, ominous! our Party dwindles dayly. What, nor Earl, nor Marquiss, nor Duke, nor ne'er a Lord? Hum, my Wine will lie most villanously upon my hands to night, Iervice. What, have we store of Knights and Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: I know not what Gentlemen there be, Sir; but there are Knights, Citizens, their Wives and Daughters.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Make us thankful for that; our Meat will not lie upon our hands then, Iervice: I'll say that for our little Londoners, they are as tall fellows at a well-charg'd Board as any in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Then, Sir, there's Nonconformist-Parsons.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay, then we shall have a cleer Board: for your true Protestant Appetite in a Lay-Elder, does a mans Table credit.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Then, Sir, there's Country-Justices and Grand-Jury-men.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well enough, well enough, Iervice.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: An't like your Worship, Mr. Wilding is come in with a Lady richly drest in Jewels, mask'd, in his hand, and will not be deny'd speaking with your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hah, rich in Jewels! this must be she. My Sword again, Iervice.— Bring 'em up, Sensure,— Prithee how do I look to night, Iervice?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Oh, most methodically, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Wild. and Diana and Betty.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Sir, I have brought into your kind protection the richest Jewel all London can afford, fair Mrs. Charlot Gettall.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Bless us, she's ravishing fair! Lady, I had the honour of being intimate with your worthy Father. I think he has been dead—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: If he chastize me much on that point, I shall spoil all. Alas, Sir, name him not; for if you do, [weeping] I'm sure I cannot answer you one Question.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: For Heaven sake, Sir, name not her Father to her; the bare remembrance of him kills her.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Alas, poor Soul! Lady, I beg your Pardon. How soft-hearted she's! I am in love; I find already a tickling kind of I know not what, run frisking through my Veins.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, the good Alderman has been dead this twelvemonth just, and has lest his Daughter here, my Mistriss, three thousand pound a year.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Three thousand pound a year! Yes, yes, I am in love.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Besides Money, Plate, and Jewels.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I'll marry her out of hand: [aside.] Alas, I cou'd even weep too; but 'tis in vain. Well, Nephew, you may be gone now: for 'tis not necessary you shou'd be seen here, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You see, Sir, now, what Heaven has done for me; and you have often told me, Sir, when that was kind, you wou'd be so. Those Writings, Sir, by which you were so good to make me Heir to all your Estate, you said you wou'd put into my possession, whene'er I made it appear to you I cou'd live without 'em, or bring you a Wife of Fortune home.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: And I will keep my word; 'tis time enough.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I have, 'tis true, been wicked; but I shall now turn from my evil ways, establish my self in the religious City, and enter into the Association. There wants but these same Writings, Sir, and your good Character of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Thou sha't have both; all in good time, man: Go, go thy ways, and I'll warrant thee for a good Character; go.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ay, Sir; but the Writings, because I told her, Sir, I was your Heir; nay, forc'd to swear it too, before she wou'd believe me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Alas, alas, how shrewdly thou wer't put to't!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I told her too, you'd buy a Patent for me: for nothing wooes a City-Fortune like the hopes of a Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I'm glad of that; that I can settle on her presently.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You may please to hint something to her of my Godly Life and Conversation; that I frequent Conventicles, and am drunk nowhere but at your true Protestant Consults and Clubs, and the like.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim,
sp.p: Nay, if these will please her, I have her for certain. [aside.] Go, go, fear not my good word.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But the Writings, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Am I a Jew, a Turk? Thou sha't have any thing, now I find thee a Lad of Parts, and one that can provide so well for thy Uncle.

div.stage: Puts him out, and addresses himself to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Wou'd they were hang'd that unjust you, that have but the Art of Lejerdemain, and can open the Japan-Cabinet in your Bed-chamber, where I know those Writings are kept. Death, what a disappointment's here! I wou'd a'sworn, this Sham had past upon him.— But, Sir, shall I not have the Writings now?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What not gone yet! for shame, away: Canst thou distrust thy own natural Uncle? Fie, away, Tom, away.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Plague upon your damn'd Dissimulation, that never-failing 〈◊〉 of all your Party, there's always mischief at the bottom on't; I know ye all; and Fortune be the Word. When next I see you, Uncle, it shall cost you dearer.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: An't please your Worship, Supper's almost over, and you are askt for.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: They know I never sup: I shall come time enough to bid 'em welcome.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I keep you, Sir, from Supper and better Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Lady, were I a Glutton, I cou'd be satisfi'd
With feeding on those two bright starry Eyes.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: You are a Courtier, Sir; we City-maids do seldom hear such Language: in which you shew your kindness to your Nephew, more than your-thoughts of what my Beauty merits.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, how innocent she is! [aside.] My Nephew, Madam? yes, yes, I cannot chuse but be wonderous kind upon his score.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Nay, he has often told me, you were the best of Uncles, and he deserves your goodness; so hopeful a young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd see't.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: So modest.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes, ask my Maids.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: So civil.
