sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes, to my Neighbours Wives. [aside.] But so, Madam, I find by this high Commendations of my Nephew, your Ladyship has a very slender opinion of your devoted Servant the while; or else, Madam, with this not disagreeable face and shape of mine, six thousand pound a year, and other Vertues and Commodities that shall be nameless, I see no reason why I should not beget an Heir of my own Body, had I the helping hand of a certain victorious person in the world, that shall be nameless.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Meaning me, I am sure: If I shou'd marry him now, and disappoint my dear Inconstant with an Heir of his own begetting, 'twou'd be a most wicked Revenge for past Kindnesses.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I know your Ladyship is studying now who this victorious person shou'd be, whom I dare not name; but let it suffice she is, Madam, within a mile of an Oak.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: No, Sir, I was considering, if what you say be true,
How unadvisedly I have lov'd your Nephew,
Who swore to me he was to be your Heir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: My Heir, Madam! am I so visibly old to be so desperate?
No, I'm in my years of desires and discretion,
And I have thoughts, durst I but utter 'em;
But modestly say, Mum—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: I took him for the hopefullest Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Let him hope on, so will I; and yet, Madam, in consideration of your love to him, and because he is my Nephew, young, handsome, witty, and soforth, I am content to be so much a Parent to him, as, if Heaven please,— to see him fairly hang'd.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: He has deserv'd it, Madam; First, for lampooning the Reverend City, with its noble Government, with the Right Honourable Gown-men; libelling some for Feasting, and some for Fasting, some for Cuckolds, and some for Cuckold-makers; charging us with all the seven deadly sins, the sins, of our Forefathers, adding seven score more to the number; the sins of Forty One reviv'd again in Eighty One, with Additions and Amendments: for which, though the Writings were drawn by which I made him my whole Executor, I will dis-inherit him. Secondly, Madam, he deserves hanging for seducing and most feloniously bearing away a young City-Heiress.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Undone, undone! Oh with what face can I return again!
What man of Wealth or Reputation, now
Will think me worth the owning!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Madam, there are honest, discreet, religious and true Protestant Knights in the City, that would be proud to dignifie and distinguish so worthy a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Look to your hits, and take fortune by the forelock, Madam.
— Alas, Madam, no Knight, and poor too!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: As a Tory-Poet.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Well▪ Madam, take comfort; if the worst come to the worst, you have Estate enough for both.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Aye, Betty, were he but honest, Betty.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Honest! I think he will not steal; but for his Body, the Lord have mercy upon't, for he has none.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: 'Tis evident I am betray'd, abus'd;
H'as lookt, and sigh'd, and talkt away my Heart;
H'as sworn and vow'd, and flatter'd me to ruine.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: A small fault with him; he has flatter'd and sworn me out of many a fair thousand: Why he has no more Conscience than a Polititian, nor no more Truth than a Narrative (under the Rose.)

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Is there no Truth nor Honesty i'th' World?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Troth, very little, and that lies all i'th' City, amongst us sober Magistrates.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Were I a man, how wou'd I be reveng'd!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Your Ladyship might do it better as you are, were I worthy to advise you.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Name it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why by marrying your Ladyships most assur'd Friend, and most humble Servant, Timothy Treat-all of London, Alderman.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Aye, this is something, Mistriss; here's Reason!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: But I have given my Faith and Troth to Wilding, Betty.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Faith and Troth! We stand upon neither Faith nor Troth in the City, Lady. I have known an Heiress married and bedded, and yet with the advice of the wiser Magistrates, has been unmarried and consummated anew with another, so it stands with our Interest; 'tis Law by Magna Charta. Nay, had you married my ungracious Nephew, we might by this our Magna Charta have hang'd him for a Rape.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: What, though he had my consent?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: That's nothing, he had not ours.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Then shou'd I marry you by stealth, the danger wou'd be the same.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No, no, Madam, we never accuse one another; 'tis the poor Rogues, the Tory Rascals, we always hang. Let 'em accuse me if they please, alas, I come off hand-smooth with Ignoramus.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Sir, there's such calling for your Worship! They are all very merry, the Glasses go briskly about.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Go, go, I'll come when all the Healths are past; I love no Healths.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: They are all over, Sir, and the Ladies are for dancing; so they are all adjourning from the Dining-room hither, as more commodious for that Exercise. I think they're coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hah, coming! Call Sensure to wait on the Lady to her Apartment.— And, Madam, I do most heartily recommend my most humble Address to your most judicious consideration, hoping you will most vigorously, and with all your might, maintain the Rights and Privil dges of the honourable City; and not suffer the force or perswasion of any Arbitrary Lover whatsoever, to subvert their Ancient and Fundamental Laws, by seducing and forcibly bearing away so rich and so illustrious a Lady: and, Madam, we will unanimously stand by you with our Lives and Fortunes.— This I learnt from a Speech at the Election of a Burgess.

div.stage: Leads her to the door: she goes out with Betty and Sensure.
Enter Musick playing, Sir Anthony Meriwill dancing with a Lady in his hand, Sir Charles with Lady Galliard, several other women and men.

lg.l: Philander was a jolly Swain,
And lov'd by ev'ry Lass;
Whom when he met upon the Plain,
He laid upon the Grass.
And here he kist, and there he play'd
With this, and then the tother,
Till every wanton smiling Maid.
At last became a Mother.
And to her Swain, and to her Swain,
The Nymph begins to yield;
Ruffle, and breathe, then to't again,
Thou'rt Master of the Field.

div.stage: Clapping Sir Char. on the back.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: And if I keep it not, say I'm a Coward, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: More Wine there, Boys, I'll keep the Humour up.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: How! young Meriwill so close to the Widow!—
Madam—

div.stage: [Addressing himself to her, Sir Char. puts him by.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Sir Timothy, why what a Pox dost thou bring that damn'd Puritanical, Schismatical, Phanatical, Small beer-face of thine into good Company? Give Him a full Glass to the Widow's Health.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: O lack, Sir Charles, no Healths for me, I pray.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Heark ye, leave that couzening, canting, sanctin'd Sneer of yours and drink ye me like a sober loyal Magistrate, all those Healths you are behind, from his sacred Majesty, whom God long preserve, with the rest of the Royal Family, even down to this wicked Widow, whom Heaven soon convert from her lewd designes upon my Body.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: A rare Boy! he shall have all my Estate.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, the Widow a lewd designe upon his Body! Nay, then I am jealous.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: I a lewd designe upon your Body! for what, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why, for villanous Matrimony.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Who, I!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Who, you? yes, you.
Why are those Eyes drest in inviting Love?
Those soft bewitching Smiles, those rising Breasts,
And all those Charms that make you so adorable,
Is't not to draw Fools into Matrimony?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: How's that, how's that! Charles at his Adorables and Charms! He must have t'other Health, he'll fall to his old Dog-trot again else. Come, come, every man his Glass. Sir Timothy, you are six behind. Come, Charles, name 'em all.

div.stage: [Each take a Glass, and force Sir Tim. on his knees.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: — Not ●ate ye an Ace, Sir: Come, his Majesties Health, and Confusion to his Enemies,

div.stage: [They go to force his mouth open to drink.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, hold, if I must drink, I must; but this is very Arbitrary, methinks.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: And now, Sir, to the Royal Duke of Albany. Musick, play a Scotch Jig.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: This is meer Tyranny.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Sir, there is just alighted at the Gate a Person of Quality, as appears by his Train, who give him the Title of a Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, a strange Lord! Conduct him up with Ceremony, Iervice.— 'Ods so, he's here!

div.stage: Enter Wilding in disguise, Dresswell, and Footmen and Pages.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Sir, by your Reverend Aspect, you shou'd be the Renown'd Mester de Hotell?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Meter de Otell! I have not the honour to know any of that name; I am call'd Sir Timothy Treat-all.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The same, Sir: I have been bred abroad, and thought all Persons of Quality had spoke French.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Not City Persons of Quality, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'm glad on'●, Sir: for 'tis a Nation I hate, as indeed I do all Monarchies.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hum! hate Monarchy! Your Lordship is most welcome.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Unless Elective Monarchies, which so resemble a Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Right, my Lord; where every man may hope to take his turn.— Your Lordship is most singularly welcome.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And though I am a stranger to your Person, I am not to your Fame, amongst the sober Party of the Amsterdamians, all the French Hugonots throughout Geneva; even to Hungary and Poland, fames trumpet sounds your praise, making the Pope to fear, the rest admire you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I'm much oblig'd to the Renowned Mobily.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So you will say, when you shall hear my Embassie. The Polanders by me salute you, Sir, and have in this next new Election, prickt ye down for their succeeding King.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, my Lord, prickt me down for a King! Why this is wonderful! Prickt me, unworthy me, down for a King! How cou'd I merit this amazing Glory!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: They know, he that can be so great a Patriot to his Native Country, where but a private person, what must he be when Power is on his side?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Aye, my Lord, my Country, my bleeding Country! there's the stop to all my rising Greatness. Shall I be so ungrateful to disappoint this big expecting Nation? defeat the sober Party, and my Neighbours, for any Polish Crown? But yet, my Lord, I will consider on't: Mean time my House is yours.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I've brought you, Sir, the measure of the Crown: Hah, it sits you to a hair. [Pulls out a Ribon and measures his head. You were by Heaven and Nature fram'd that Monarch.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Hah, at it again! [Sir Charles making sober love.] Come, we grow dull, Charles: where stands the Glass? what, balk my Lady Galliard's Health!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Hah, Galliard— and so sweet on Meriwill!

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: If it be your business, Sir, to drink, I'll withdraw.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Gad, and I'll withdraw with you, Widow. Heark ye, Lady Galliard, I am damnably afraid you cannot bear your Liquor well, you are so forward to leave good Company and a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, since I have done what I never do, to oblige you, I hope you'll not refuse a Health of my Denomination.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: We scorn to be so uncivil.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why then here's a conceal'd Health that shall be nameless, to his Grace the King of Poland.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: King of Poland! Lord, Lord, how your thoughts ramble!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Not so far as you imagine; I know what I say, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Away with it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I see, Sir, you still keep up that English Hospitality that so renowned our Ancestors in History.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Aye, my Lord, my noble Guests are my Wife and Children.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Are you not married then? Death, she smiles on him!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I had a Wife, but, rest her Soul, she's dead; and I have no Plague left now, but an ungracious Nephew, perverted with Ill Customs, Tantivie-Opinions, and Court-Notions.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Cannot your pious Examples convert him?
By Heaven, she's fond of him!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Alas, I hav●●●y'd all ways, fair and foul; ●ay, had settled t'other day my whole Estate upon him, and just as I had sign'd the Writings, out comes me a damn'd Libel call'd, A Warning to all good Christians against the City-Magistrates; and I doubt he had a hand in Absolon and Achitophel; a Rogue: But some of our sober Party have claw'd him home, i'faith, and given him Rhyme for his Reason.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Most visibly in love!— Oh, Sir, Nature, Laws, and Religion, plead for so neer a Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Laws and Religion! Alas, my Lord, he deserves not the name of a Patriot, who does not for the Publick Good defie all Laws and Religion.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Death, I must interrupt 'em!— Sir, pray what Lady's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I beseech your Lordship, know her, 'tis my Lady Galliard: ' the rest are all my Friends and Neighbours, true Protestants all— Well, my Lord, how do you like my method of doing the Business of the Nation, and carrying on the Cause with Wine, Women, and soforth.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: High feeding and smart Drinking, gains more to the Party, than your smart Preaching.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Your Lordship has hit it right: A rare man this!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But come, Sir, leave we serious affairs, and oblige these fair ones.

div.stage: Addresses himself to Galliard, Sir Charles puts him by.
Enter Charlot disguised Clacket, and Fopington.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Heavens, Clacket, yonders my false one, and that my lovely Rival.

div.stage: Pointing to Wild. and L. Gall.
Enter Diana and Sensure maskt, and Betty.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Sensure, this Favour has oblig'd me.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: I hope you'll not discover it to his Worship, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By her meen, this shou'd be handsome.— [Goes to Diana.] Madam, I hope you have not made a Resolution to deny me the honour of your hand.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Hah, Wilding! Love can discover thee through all disguise.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Hah, Diana! Wou'd 'twere Felony to wear a Vizard. Gad, I'd rather meet it on the Kings Highway with Stand and Deliver, than thus encounter it on the Face of an old Mistriss; and the Cheat were more excusable.— But how—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Nay, never frown nor chide: for thus do I intend to shew my Authority, till I have made thee onely fit for me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Is't so, my precious Uncle! are you so great a Devil in Hypocrisie! Thus had I been serv'd, had I brought him the right woman.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: But do not think, dear Tommy, I wou'd have serv'd thee so; married thy Uncle, and have cozen'd thee of thy Birthright.— But see, we're observ'd!

div.stage: Charlot listening behind him all this while.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: By all that's good, 'tis he! that Voice is his!

div.stage: He going from Dian. turns upon Charlot and looks.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Hah, what pretty Creature's this, that has so much of Charlot in her face? But sure she durst not venture: 'tis not her dress nor meen. Dear pretty stranger, I must dance with you.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Gued deed, and see ye shall, Sir, ●en you please. Tho l's not dance, Sir, I's tell ya that noo.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nor I: so we're well matcht. By Heaven, she's wonderous like her.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: By th' Mass, not so kind, Sir: 'Twere gued that ene of us shou'd dance to guid the other weel.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How young, how innocent, and free she is?
And wou'd you, fair one, be guided by me?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: In any thing that gued is.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I love you extreamly, and wou'd teach you to love.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Ah, wele aday!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A thing I know you do not understand.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Gued faith, and ya're i'th' right, Sir; yet 'tis a thing I's often hear ya gay men talk of.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes, and no doubt have been told those pretty Eyes inspired it.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Gued deed, and so I have: Ya men make sa mickle ado aboot ens Eyes, ways me, I's ene tir'd with sick-like Compliments.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ah, if you give us Wounds, we must complain.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Ya may ene keep out a harms way then.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh, we cannot; or if we cou'd, we wou'd not.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Marry and I's have ene a Song tol that tune, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Dear Creature, let me beg it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Gued faith, ya shall not, Sir, I's sing without entreaty.

lg.l: Ah, Jenny, gen your Eyes do kill,
You'll let me tell my pain;
Gued faith, I lov'd against my will,
But wad not break my Chain.
I once was call'd a bonny Lad,
Till that fair face if yours
Betray'd the freedom once I had,
And ad my bleether howers.
But noo ways me, like Winter looks,
My gloomy showering Eyne,
And on the banks of shaded Brooks,
I pass my wearied time.
I call the Streem that gleedeth on,
To witness if it see,
On all the flowry Brink along,
A Swain so true as Iee.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: This very Swain am I, so true and so forlorn, unless you pity me. This is an excellently Charlot wants, at least I never heard her sing.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Why Charles, where stands the woman, Charles? Fop. comes up to Charlot.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I must speak to Galliard, though all my Fortunes depend on the discovery of my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Come, come, a cooling Glass about.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Dear Dresswell, entertain Charles Meriwill a little, whilst I speak to Galliard.
sp.stage: The men go all to the Drinking-table.
sp.l: By Heaven, I die, I languish for a word!
— Madam, I hope you have not made a Vow
To speak with none but that young Cavalier?
They say, the freedom English Ladies use,
Is as their Beauty, great.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Sir, we are none of those of so nice and delicate a Vertue as Conversation can corrupt; we live in a cold Climate.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And think you're not so apt to be in love,
As where the Sun shines oftner.
But you too much partake of the Inconstancy of this your fickle Chmat●
One day all Sun-shine, and th' encourag'd Lover
Decks himself up in glittering Robes of Hope;
And in the midst of all their boasted Finery
Comes a dark Cloud across his Mistriss Brow,
Dashes the Fool, and spoils the gawdy show.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hah, do not I know that railing Tongue of yours?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: 'Tis from your Guilt, not Judgment then.
I was resolv'd to be to night a Witness
Of that sworn Love you flatter'd me so often with.
By Heaven, I saw you playing with my Rival,
Sigh'd, and lookt Babies in his gloating Eyes.
When is the Assignation? when the Hours?
For he's impatient as the raging Sea,
Loose as the Winds, and amorous as the Sun
That kisses all the Beauties of the Spring.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I take him for a soberer person, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Have I been the Companion of his Riots
In all the lewd course of our early Youth,
Where like unwearied Bees we gather'd Flowers?
But no kind Blossome cou'd oblige our stay,
We rifled and were gone.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Your Vertues I perceive are pretty equal;
Onely his Love's the honester o'th' two.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Honester! that is, he wou'd owe his good fortune to the Parson of the Parish;
sp.l: And I wou'd be oblig'd to you alone.
He wou'd have a License to boast he lies with you,
And I wou'd do't with modesty and silence:
For Vertue's but a name kept free from Scandal,
Which the most base of women best preserve,
Since Gilting and Hypocrisie cheat the world best.
— But we both love, and who shall blab the secret?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Oh, why were all the Charms of Speaking given to that false Tongue that makes no better use of 'em?
sp.l: — I'll hear no more of your inchanting Reasons.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You must.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Indeed you must.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: By all the Powers above—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By all the powers of Love, you'll break your Oath, unless you swear this night to let me see you.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: This night?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: This very night.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I'd die first— At what hour?

div.stage: [First turns away, then Sighs and looks on him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: O●, name it; and if I fail—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I wou'd not for the World—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: That I shou'd fail!

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Not name the guilty hour.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Then I through eager haste shall come too soon,
And do your Honour wrong.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: My Honour! Oh that word!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Which the Devil was in me for naming.
— At Twelve!

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: My Women and my Servants then are up.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: At One, or Two.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: So late! 'twill be so quickly day!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Aye, so it will:
That half our business will be left unfinisht.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hah, what do you mean? what business?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: A thousand tender things I have to say,
A thousand Vows of my eternal love.;
And now and then we'll kiss and—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Be extreamly honest.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: As you can wish.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Rather as I command: for shou'd he know my wish, I were undone.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: The Signe.—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Oh, press me not;— yet you may come at midnight under my Chamber-window.

div.stage: [Sir Char. seas 'em so close, comes to 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, hold! Whilst I am listening to the relation of your French
Fortifications, Outworks, and Counterscarps, I perceive the Enemy in my Quarters.
— My Lord, by your leave.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Perswade me not; I burst with Jealousie.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Death and the Devil Clacket! then 'tis Charlot, and I'm discover'd to her.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Say, are not you a false dissembling thing?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What, my little Northern Lass translated into English!
This 'tis to practise Art in spight of Nature.
●as, thy Vertue, Youth, and Innocence,
Were never made for Cunning.
I found ye out through all your forc'd Disguise.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Hah, did you know me then?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: At the first glance, and found you knew me too,
And talkt to yonder Lady in revenge,
Whom my Uncle wou'd have me marry. But to avoid all discourses of that nature,
I came to night in this disguise you see, to be conceal'd from her; that's all.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: And is that all, on honour? is it, Dear?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What, no Belief, no Faith in villanous women?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Yes, when I see the Writings.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Go home; I die if you shou'd be discover'd;
And credit me, I'll bring you all you ask.
Clacket, you and I must have an odde Reckoning about this nights jant of yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Well, my Lord, how do you like our English Beauties?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Extreamly, Sir; and was pressing his young Lady to give us a Song.

div.stage: Here is an Italian Song in two parts.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: I never saw this Lady before: pray who may she be, Neighbour?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.l: A Niece of mine, newly come out of Scotland, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay, then she dances by nature. Gentlemen and Ladies, please you to sit, here's a young Neighbour of mine will honour us with a Dance.
sp.stage: They all sit; Charl. and Fop. dance.
sp.p: So, so; very well, very well. Gentlemen and ladies, I am for Liberty of Conscience, and Moderation. There's a Banquet waits the Ladies, and my Cellars are open to the men; but for my self, I must retire: first waiting on your Lordship to shew you your Apartment, then leave you to cher entire; and tomorrow, my Lord, you and I will settle the Nation, and resolve on what return we will make to the noble Polanders.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Wild. Dress. and Fop. Sir Char. leading out L. Gall.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Well said, Charles, thou leavest her not, till she's thy own, Boy.— And
Philander was a jolly Swain, &c.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: All things succeed above my wish, dear Frank;
Fortune is kind; and more, Galliard is so:
This night crowns all my Wishes.
Laboir, are all things ready for our purpose?

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.l: Dark Lanthorns, Pistols, Habits and Vizards, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.l: I have provided Portmantles to carry off the Treasure.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.l: I perceive you are resolv'd to make a through-stitcht Robbery on't.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.l: Faith, if it lie in our way, Sir, we had as good venture a Caper under the
Triple Tree for one as well as t'other.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: We will consider on't. 'tis now just struck Eleven: within this hour is the dear Assignation with Galliard.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.l: What, whether our affairs be finisht or not?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: 'Tis but at next door; I shall return time enough for that trivial business.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.l: A trivial business of some six thousand pound a year?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Trivial to a woman, Frank! no more do you make as if you went to bed.— Labour do you feign to be drunk, and lie on the Hall-table; and when I give the signe, let me softly in.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.l: Death, Sir, will you venture at such a time!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: My life and future hope— I am resolv'd,
Let Polititians plot, let Rogues go on
In the old beaten Path of Forty One,
Let City-Knaves delight in Mutiny,
The Rabble bow to old Presbytery;
Let petty States be to confusion hurl'd,
Give me but Woman, I'll despise the World.

div.head: SCENE the First. A Dressing-room.
div.stage: Lady Galliard is discover'd in an undress at her Table, Glass, and Toilette, Closet attending: As soon as the Scene draws off, she rises from the Table as disturb'd and out of humour.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: COme, leave your everlasting Chamber-Maids Chat, your dull Road of
Slandering by rote, and lay that Paint aside. Thou art fuller of false
News, than an unlicens'd Mercury.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: I have good proof, Madam, of what I say.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Proof of a thing impossible!— Away.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Is it a thing so impossible, Madam, that a man of Mr. Wilding's parts and person should get a City-Heiress?
Such a bonne Mine, and such a pleasant Wit!

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hold thy fluent Tattle, thou hast Tongue
Enough to talk an Oyster-woman deaf; I say it cannot be.—
What means the panting of my troubled Heart!
Oh my presaging fears! shou'd what she says prove true,
How wretched and how lost a thing am I!

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Your Honour may say your pleasure; but I hope I have not liv'd to these years to be impertinent:— No, Madam, I am none of those that run up and down the Town a Story-hunting, and a Lye-catching, and—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Eternal rattle, peace!—
Mrs. Charlot Gettall go away with Wilding!
A man of Wilding's extravagant life
Get a Fortune in the City!
Thou might'st as well have told me, a Holder forth were married to a Nun.
There are not two such Contraries in Nature;
'Tis flamm, 'tis foolery, 'tis most impossible.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: I beg your Ladyships pardon, if my discourse offend you; but all the world knows Mrs. Clacket to be a person—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Who is a most devout Bawd, a precise Procurer;
Saint in the Spirit, and Whore in the Flesh;
A Doer of the Devils work in Gods Name.
Is she your Informer? nay, then the Lye's undoubted.—
I say once more, adone with your idle Tittle-tattle,—
And to divert me, bid Betty sing the Song which Wilding
Made to his last Mistriss: we may judge by that
What little Haunts and what low Game he follows.
This is not like the description of a rich Citizens Daughter and Heir, but some common
Hackney of the Suburbs.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: I have heard him often swear she was a Gentlewoman, and liv'd with her
Friends.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Like enough; there are many of these Gentlewomen who live with their
Friends, as rank Prostitutes, as errant Jilts, as those who make open profession of the
Trade— almost as mercenary— But come, the Song.

lg.l: In Phillis all vile Iilts are met,
Foolish, uncertain, false, Coquette.
Love is her constant welcome Guest,
And still the newest pleases best.
Quickly she likes, then leaves as soon;
Her life on Woman's a Lampoon.
Yet for the Plague of Humane Race,
This Devil has an Angels Face;
Such Youth, such Sweetness in her look,
Who can be man, and not be took?
What former Love, what Wit, what Art,
Can save a poor inclining heart?
In vain, a thousand times an hour,
Reason rebels against her power.
In vain I rail, I curse her Charms;
One look my feeble Rage disarms.
There is Inchantment in her Eyes;
Who sees 'em, can no more be wise.

div.stage: Enter Wilding, who runs to embrace L. Gall.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Twelve was the luckie minute when we met:
Most charming of your Sex, and wisest of all Widows,
My Life, my Soul, my Heaven to come, and here!
Now I have liv'd to purpose, since at last— Oh, killing Joy!—
Come, let me sold you, press you in my arms,
And kiss you thanks for this dear happy night.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: You may spare your thanks, Sir, for those that will deserve 'em; I shall give ye no occasion for 'em.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nay, no Scruples now, dearest of Dears, no more▪
'Tis most unseasonable—
I bring a heart full fraight with eager hopes,
Opprest with a vast load of longing Love;
Let me unlade me in that soft white Bosome,
That Store-house of rich Joys and lasting Pleasures,
And lay me down as on a Bed of Lillies.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: You're wonderous full of Love and Rapture, Sir; but certainly you mistake the person you address 'em to.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why, are you not my Lady Galliard, that very Lady Galliard, who if one may take her word for't, loves Wilding? Am I not come hither by your own appointment; and can I have any other business here at this time of night, but Love, and Rapture, and—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Scandalous and vain! by my appointment, and for so lewd a purpose! guard me, ye good Angels.
sp.l: If after an Affront so gross as this,
I ever suffer you to see me more,
Then think me what your Carriage calls me▪
An Impudent, an open Prostitute,
Lost to all sense of Vertue, or of Honour.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What can this mean?
Oh, now I understand the Mystery;
Her Woman's here, that troublesome piece of Train.
sp.p: — I must remove her. Heark ve, Mrs. Closet, I had forgot to tell you; As I came up I heard a Kinsman of yours very earnest with the Servants below, and in great haste to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: A Kinsman! that's very likely indeed, and at this time of night.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes, a very neer Kinsman he said he was, your Fathers own Mothers Uncles Sisters Son; what d'ye call him?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: Aye, what d'ye call him indeed; I shou'd be glad to hear his name. Alas, Sir, I have no neer Relation living that I know of, the more's my misfortune, poor helpless Orphan that I am.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nay, but Mrs. Closet, pray take me right,
This Country-man of yours, as I was saying—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Chang'd already from a Kinsman to a Country-man! A plain contrivance to get my Woman out of the Room. Closet, as you value, my service, stir not from hence.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: This Country-man of yours, I say, being left Executor by your Fathers last will and Testament, is come— Dull Waiting-woman, I wou'd be alone with your Lady; know your Que, and retire.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Learn, I say, to understand Reason when you hear it. Leave us a while;
Love is not a Game for three to play at.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p:
I must own to all the world, you have convinc'd me; I ask a thousand Pardons for my dulness. Well, I'll be gone, I'll run; you're a most powerful person, the very Spirit of Perswasion.— I'll steal out.— You have such a taking way with you—
But I forget my self. Well, your most obedient Servant: Whenever you've occasion, Sir, be pleas'd to use me freely.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, dear Impertinent, no more Complements, you see I'm busie now; prithee be gone, you see I'm busie.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: I'm all Obedience to you, Sir—
Your most obedient—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Whither are you ●isking and gigiting now?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Madam, I am going down, and will return immediately, immediately.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So, she's gone; Heaven and broad Gold be prais'd for the deliverance: And now, dear Widow, let's lose no more pretious time; we've fool'd away too much already.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: This to me?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: To you, yes, to whom else shou'd it be? unless being sensible you have not discretion enough to manage your own affairs your self, you resolve, like other Widows, with all you're worth to buy a Governour, commonly called a Husband. I took ye to be wiser; but if that be your designe, I shall do my best to serve you— though to deal freely with you—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Trouble not your self, Sir, to make Excuses; I'm not so fond of the offer to take you at your word. Marry you! a Rakes●●●e, who have not esteem enough for the Sex to believe your own Mother honest— without Money or Credit, without Land either in present or prospect; and half a dozen hungry Vices, like so many bawling Brats at your back, perpetually craving, and more chargeable to keep than twice the number of Children. Besides, I think you are provided for; are you not married to Mrs. Charlot Gettall?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Married to her? do I know her, you shou'd rather ask. What Fool has forg'd this unlikely Lye? But suppose 'twere true, cou'd you be jealous of a woman I marry? do you take me for such an Ass, to suspect I shall love my own Wise? On the other side, I have a great charge of Vices, as you well observe, and I must not be so barbarous to let them starve. Every body in this Age takes care to provide for their Vices, though they send their Children a begging; I should be worse than an Infidel to neglect them. No, I must marry some stiff awkward thing or other with an ugly face and a handsome Estate, that's certain: but whoever is ordain'd to make my Fortune, 'tis you onely that can make me happy.— Come, do it then.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I never will.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Unkindly said, you must.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Unreasonable man! because you see
I have unusual regards for you,
Pleasure to hear, and trouble to deny you;
A fatal yielding in my nature toward you,
Love bends my Soul that way.—
A weakness I ne'er felt for any other;
And wou'd you be so base? and cou'd you have the heart
To take th' advantage on'● to ruine me,
To make me infamous, despis'd, loath'd, pointed at?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You reason false.—
According to the strictest rules of Honour,
Beauty shou'd still be the Reward of Love,
Not the vile Merchandize of Fortune,
Or the cheap Drug of a Church-Ceremony.
She's onely infamous, who to her Bed,
For interest, takes some nauseous Olown she hates:
And though a Joynture or a Vow in publick
●e her price, that makes her but the dearer whore.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I understand not these new Morals.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Have patience, I say 'tis clear.
All the desires of mutual Love are vertuous.
Can Heaven or Man be angry that you please
Your self and me, when it does wrong to none?
Why rave you then on things that ne'r can be?
Besides, are we not alone, and private? who can know it?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Heaven will know't; and I— that that's enough:
But when you're weary of me, first your Friend, then his, then all the world.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Think not that time will ever come.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Oh, it must, it will!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Or if it shou'd, cou'd I be such a Villain—
Ah Cruel! if you lov'd me as you say,
You wou'd not thus distrust me.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: You do me wrong; I love you more than ere my Tongue,
Or all the Actions of my Life can tell you— so well—
Your very faults, how gross soere, to me
Have something pleasing in 'em. To me you're all
That Man can praise, or Woman can desire;
All Charm without, and all Desert within:
But yet my Vertue is more lovely still;
That is a price too high to pay for you:
The love of Angels may be bought too dear,
If we bestow on them what's kept for Heaven.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Hell and the Devil! I'll hear no more
Of this Religious stuff, this Godly nonsence.
Death, Madam, do you bring me into your Chamber to preach Vertue to me?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I bring you hither! how can you say it?
I suffer'd you indeed to come, but not
For the base end you fancy'd, but to take
A last leave of you. Let my heart break with Love,
I cannot be that wretched thing you'd have me:
Believe I still shall have a kindness for you,
Always your Friend, your Mistriss now no more.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Cozen'd, abus'd, she loves some other man!
Dull Blockhead not to find it out before!
— Well, Madam, may I at last believe
This is your fixt and final Resolution?
And does your Tongue now truly speak your Heart,
That has so long bely'd it?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: It does.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I'm glad on't. Good night: And when I visit you again,
May you again thus fool me.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Stay but a moment.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: For what? to praise your Night-dress, or make court to your little Dog? No, no, Madam, send for Mr. Flamfull and Mr. Flutterbuz, Mr. Lapp-fool and Mr. Love-all; they'll do it better, and are more at leisure.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Hear me a little: You know I both despise, and hate those civil Coxcombs, as much as Lesteem and love you. But why will you be gone so soon? and why are you so cruel to urge me thus to part either with your good Opinion or your Kindness? I wou'd fain keep 'em both.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Then keep your word, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: My word! And have I promis'd then to be
A Whore? A Whore! Oh let me think of that!
A man's Convenience, his leisure hours, his Bed of Ease,
To loll and tumble on at idle times;
The Slave, the Hackney of his lawless Lust!
A loath'd Extinguisher of filthy flames,
Made use of, and thrown by.— Oh infamous!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Come, come, you love me not, I see it plain;
That makes your scruples: that, that's the reason
You start at words, and run away from shadows.
Already some pert Fop, some Ribon-fool,
Some dancing Coxcomb, has supplanted me
In that unsteady treacherous woman's heart of yours.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Believe it if you will. Yes, let me be false, unjust, ungrateful, any thing but a— Whore—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Oh, Sex on purpose form'd to plague Mankind!
All that you are, and that you do, 's a lye.
False are your Faces, false your floating Hearts;
False are your Quarrels, false your Reconcilements:
Enemies without Reason, and Dear without Kindness.
Your Friendship's false, but much more false your Love;
Your damn'd deceitful Love is all o'er false.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: False rather are the Joys you are so fond of.
Be wise, and cease, Sir, to pursue 'em farther.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: No, them I can never quit; but you most easily.
A woman changeable, and false as you.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Said you most easily? Oh, inhumane!
Your cruel words have wak'd a dismal thought;
I feel 'em cold and heavy at my heart,
And weakness steals upon my Soul apace;
I find I must be miserable.—
I would not be thought false.

div.stage: [In a soft tone, coming neer him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nor wou'd I think you so; give me not cause.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: What heart can bear distrust from what it loves?
Or who can always her own Wish deny?
My Reason's weary of the unequal strise;
And Love and Nature will at last o'ercome.
— Do you not then believe I love you?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How can I, while you still remain unkind?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: How shall I speak my guilty thoughts?—
sp.p: I have not power to part with you: conceal my shame I doubt I cannot, I fear I wou'd not any more deny you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh, heavenly sound! Oh, charming Creature! speak that word again, agen, agen! for ever let me hear it.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: But did you not indeed? and will you never, never love Mrs. Charlot, never?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Never, never.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Turn your face away, and give me leave
To hide my rising Blushes: I cannot look on you,
sp.stage: As this last Speech is speaking she sinks into his Arms by degrees.
sp.l: But you must undo me if you will.—
Since I no other way my truth can prove,
— You shall see I love.
Pity my Weakness, and admire my Love.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: All Heaven is mine, I have it in my arms:
Nor can ill Fortune reach me any more.
Fate, I defie thee, and dull World, adieu.
In Loves kind Fever let me ever ly,
Drunk with Desire, and raving mad with Joy.

div.stage: Exeunt into the Bed-chamber, Wild. leading her with his arms about her.
Enter Sir Charles Meriwill and Sir Anthony, Sir Char. drunk.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: A Dog, a Rogue, to leave her!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Why look ye, Uncle, what wou'd you have a man do?
I brought her to her Coach.—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: To her Coach! to her Coach! Did not I put her into your hand, follow'd you out, winkt, smil'd, and nodded, cry'd, ' buy Charles, ' buy Rogue; which was as much as to say, Go home with her, Charles, home to her Chamber, Charles; nay, as much as to say, Home to her Bed, Charles▪ nay, as much as to say— Hum, hum, a Rogue, a Dog, and yet to be modest too! That I shou'd bring thee up with no more fear of God before my Eyes!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Nay, dear Uncle, don't break my heart now. Why I did proffer, and press, and swear, and ly'd, and— but a Pox on her, she has the damndest wheedling way with her, as, Dear Charles, nay prithee, he, 'tis late, to morrow, my Honour, which if you lov'd, you wou'd preserve; and such obliging Reasons.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Reasons! Reason! a Lover, and talk of Reason! You lye, Sirrah, you lye. Leave a woman for Reason, when you were so finely drunk too, a Rascal!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why look ye, d'ye see, Uncle, I durst not trust my self alone with her in this pickle, lest I shou'd a fallen soul on her.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Why there's it; 'tis that you shou'd adone: I am mistaken if she be not one of those Ladies that love to be ravisht of a Kindness. Why, your willing Rape is all the fashion, Charles.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: But heark ye, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Why how now, Jack-sawce, what, capitulate?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why do but hear me, Uncle: Lord you're so hasty! Why look ye, I am as ready, d'ye see, as any man 〈◊〉 these occasions.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Are you so, Sir? and I'll make you willing, or try Toledo with you, Sir.— Whe, what, I shall have ye whining when you are sober again, traversing your Chamber with Arms across, railing on Love and Women, and at last defeated, turn whipping Tom, to revenge your self on the whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: My dear Uncle, come kiss me and be friends, I will be rul'd

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: — A most admirable good-natur'd Boy this! [aside.] Well then, dear Charles, know, I have brought thee now hither to the Widows house with a resolution to have thee order matters so, as before thou quits her, she shall be thy own, Boy.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Gad, Uncle, thou'rt a Cherubin! Introduce me, d'ye see, and if I do not so woo the Widow, and so do the Widow, that are morning she shall be content to take me for better for worse.— Renounce me! Egad, I'll make her know the Lord God from Tom Bell, before I have done with her. Nay, backt by my noble Uncle, I'll venture on her, had she all Cupid's Arrows, Venus's Beauty, and Ma●alina's Fire, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: A sweet Boy, a very sweet Boy! Hum, thou art damnable handsome to night, Charles.— Aye, thou wilt do't; I see a kind of a resistless Lewdness about thee, a most triumphant Impudence, loose and wanton.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Heavens, Gentlemen, what makes you here at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Where's your Lady?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Softly, dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Why is she asleep? Come, come, I'll wake her.

div.stage: Offers to force in as to the Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Hold, hold, Sir: No, no, she's a little busie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: I'll have no business done to night, Sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Hold, hold, I beseech you, Sir, her Mother's with her: For Heavens sake,
Sir, be gone.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: I'll not budge.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: No not a foot.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: The City you know, Sir, is so 〈◊〉—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Damn the City.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: All the Whigs, Charles, all the Whigs.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: In short, I am resolv'd, d'ye see, to go to the Widows Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Heark ye, Mrs. Closet, I thought I had intirely engag'd you this evening.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: I am perfectly yours, Sir; but now it happens so, her Mother being there—
Yet if you wou'd withdraw for half an hour, into my Chamber, till she were gone—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: This is Reason, Charles. Here, here's two Pieces to buy thee a Gorget.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: And here's my two, because 〈…〉 illustrious.

div.stage: Gives her Money● and goes out with her.
Enter Lady Galliard in rage, held by Wilding.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: What have I done? Ah, whither shall I flie?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Why all these Tears? Ah, why this cruel Passion?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Undone, undone! Unhand me, false, sorsworn;
Be gone, and let me rage till I am dead.
What shou'd I do with guilty Life about me?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Why, where's the harm of what we two have done?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Ah, leave me—
Leave me alone to sigh to flying Winds,
That the infection may be born aloft,
And reach no humane Ear.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Cease, lovely Charmer, cease to wound me more.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Shall I survive this shame! No, if I do,
Eternal Blushes dwell upon my Cheeks,
To tell the World my Crime.
— Mischief and Hell, what Devil did possess me?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: It was no Devil, but a Deity;
A little gay-wing'd God, harmless and innocent,
Young as Desire, wanton as Summer-breezes,
Soft as thy Smiles, resistless as thy Eyes.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Ah, what malicious God,
Sworn Enemy to feeble Womankind,
Taught thee the Art of Conquest with thy Tongue?
Thy false deluding Eyes were surely made
Of Stars that rule our Sexes Destiny:
And all thy Charms were by Inchantment wrought,
That first undo the heedless Gazers on,
Then shew their natural deformity.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Ah, my Galliard, am I grown ugly then?
Has my increase of Passion lessen'd yours?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Peace tempter, Peace, who artfully betrayest me,
And then upbraidest the wretchedness thou'st made.
— Ah, Fool, eternal Fool! to know my danger,
Yet venture on so evident a ruine.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Say,— what one Grace is faded!
Is not thy Face as fair, thy Eyes as Killing?
By Heaven, much more: This charming change of Looks,
Raises my flame, and makes me wish t'invoke
The harmless God again.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: By Heaven, not all thy Art
Shall draw me to the tempting sin again.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Oh, I must, or dye.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: By all the Powers, by—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Oh, do not swear, lest Love shou'd take it ill
That Honour shou'd pretend to give him Laws,
And make an Oath more powerful than his Godhead.
— Say that you will half a long hour hence—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Or say a tedious hour.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Death, never—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Or if you must— promise me then to morrow.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: No, hear my Vows.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Hold, see me die; if you resolve 'em fatal to my love, by Heaven I'll do't.

div.stage: Lays his hand on his Sword.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Ah, what—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Revoke that fatal Never then.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Oh, say you will.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Alas, I dare not utter it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Let's in, and thou shalt whisper it into my Bosom;
Or sighing, look it to me with thy Eyes.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Ah, Wilding—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: It toucht my Soul! Repeat that sigh again.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Ah, I confess I am but feeble woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Good Mistriss keep-door, stand by: for I must enter.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hah, young Meriwill's voice!

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Pray, Sir Charles, let me go and give my Lady notice.
sp.stage: She enters and goes to Wild.
sp.l: — For Heavens sake, Sir, withdraw, or my Lady's Honour's lost.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What will you have me do?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Be gone, or you will ruine me for ever.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nay, then I will obey.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Here, down the back-stairs.—
As you have Honour, go and cherish mine.
— He's gone; and now methinks the shivering fit of Honour is return'd.

div.stage: Enter Sir Charles, rudely pushing Closet aside, with Sir Anthony.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Deni'd an entrance! nay, then there is a Rival in the case, or so; and
I'm resolv'd to discover the Hellish Plot, d'ye see.

div.stage: Iust as he enters drunk at one door, Wild. returns at the other.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Ha, Wilding return'd! shield me, ye Shades of Night.

div.stage: Puts out the Candles, and goes to Wild.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: The back-stairs-door is lockt.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Oh, I am lost! curse on this fatal night!
Art thou resolv'd on my undoing every way?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Nay, now we're by dark, let me alone to guide you, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: What, what, all in darkness? Do you make Love like Cats, by Star-light?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Ah, he knows he's here!— Oh, what a pain is Guilt!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I wou'd not be surpriz'd.

div.stage: As Closet takes him to lead him out, he takes out his Sword, and by dark, pushes by Sir Charles, and almost overthrows Sir Anthony; at which they both draw, whilst he goes out with Closet.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Hah, Gad 'twas a Spark!— What, vanisht! hah—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Nay, nay, Sir, I am for ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Are you so, Sir? and I am for the Widow, Sir, and—
sp.stage: Iust as they are passing at each other, Closet enters with a Candle.
sp.l: — Hah, why what have we here,— my none flesh and blood?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Cry mercy, Sir! Pray how fell we out?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ou●, Sir! Prithee where's my Rival? where's the Spark, the— Gad, I took thee for an errant Rival: Where, where is he?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Whom seek ye, Sir, a man, and in my Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: A man! merciful, what will this scandalous lying World come to? Here's no man.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Away, I say, thou damn'd Domestick Intelligence, that comest out every half hour with some fresh Sham.— No man!— What, 'twas an appointment onely, hum,— which I shall now make bold to unappoint, render null, void, and of none effect. And if I find him here [searches about] I shall very civilly and accidentally, as it were, being in perfect friendship with him— pray mark that— run him through the Lungs.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Oh, what a Coward's guilt! what mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Mean! why I am obstinately bent to ravish thee, thou hypocritical Widow, make thee mine by force, that so I may have no obligation to thee, and consequently use thee scurvily with a good Conscience.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: A most delicate Boy! I'll warrant him as lewd as the best of 'em, God grant him life and Health.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: 'Tis late, and I entreat your absence, Sir: These are my hours of prayer, which this unseasonable Visit has disturb'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Prayer! no more of that, Sweetheart: for let me tell you, your Prayers are heard. A Widow of your Youth and Complexion can be praying for nothing so late, but a good Husband; and see, Heaven has sent him just in the crit— critical minute, to supply your occasions.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: A Wag, an arch Wag; he'll learn to make Lampoons presently. I'll not give sixpence from him, though to the Poor of the Parish.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Come, Widow, let's to bed.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, you drive the Jest too far;
And I am in no humour now for mirth.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Jest! Gad ye lye, I was never in more earnest in all my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: He's in a heavenly humour, thanks to good Wine, good Counsel, and good Company.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir? what can my Woman think to see me treated thus?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Well thought on! Nay, we'll do things decently, d'ye see—
Therefore, thou sometimes necessary Utensil, withdraw.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: Aye, aye, let me alone to reach her her duty.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Stay, Closet, I command ye.
— What have you seen in me shou'd move you to this rudeness?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p:
No drowning; for by this dear night, 'tis charity, care of your Reputation, Widow: and therefore I am resolv'd nobody shall lie with you but my self.
You have dangerous 〈◊〉 buzzing about your Hive, Widow— mark that— [She flings from him.] Nay, no parting but upon terms, which in short, d'ye see, are these: Down on your knees, and swear me heartily as God shall judge your Soul, d●ye see, to marry me to morrow.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: To morrow! Oh, I have urgent business then.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: So have I. Nay Gad, an you be for the neerest way to wood, the sober discreet way of loving, I am for you, look ye.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, what mean you?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Onely to go to bed, that's all.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hold, hold, or I'll call out.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Aye do, call up a Jury of your Female Neighbours; they'll be for me, d'ye see, bring in the Bill Ignoramus, though I am no very true blue Protestant neither: Therefore dispatch, or—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hold, are you mad? I cannot promise you to night.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll be content with performance then to night, and trust you for your promise till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: [peeping.] Ah, Rogue! By George, he out-does my expectations of him.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: What Imposition's this! I'll call for help.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: You need not, you'll do my business better alone.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: What shall I do! how shall I send him hence!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: He shall ne'er drink small Beer more, that's positive: I'll burn all's Books too, they have helpt to spoil him; and sick or well, found or unsound, Drinking shall be his Diet, and Whoring his Study.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Come, come, no pausing; your promise, or I'll to bed.

div.stage: Offers to pull off his Breeches, having pull'd off almost all the rest of his Clothes.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: What shall I do, here is no Witness neer! And to be rid of him, I'll promise him: he'll have forgot it in his sober Passion.
sp.stage: [aside. He fumbling to undo his Breetches.
sp.p: Hold, I do swear I will—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Marry you.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Nay, that's too much.— Hold, hold, I will to morrow.
— Now you are satisfi'd, you will withdraw?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Charles, Joy Charles, give ye Joy: here's two substantial Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: I deny it, Sir; I heard no such thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What, what, Mrs. Closet, a Waiting-woman of Honour, and flinch from her Evidence! Gad, I'll damn thy Soul, if thou darest swear what thou sayest.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: How, upon the catch, Sir! am I betray'd?
Base and unkind, is this your humble Love!
Is all your whining come to this, false man! By Heaven, I'll be reveng'd.

div.stage: She goes out in rage, with Closet.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Nay, Gad you're caught, struggle and Flounder as you please, Sweetheart, you'll but intangle more; let me alone to tickle your Gills, ●●aith.
— Uncle, get ye home about your business: I hope you'll give me the Good morrow, as becomes me.— I say no more— A word to the Wise—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: By George, thou'rt a brave fellow; why I did not think it had been in thee, man. Well, adieu: I'll give thee such a Good morrow, Charles— the Devil's in him!— ' Buy, Charles— a plaguie Rogue!— ' Night, Boy— a Divine Youth!

div.stage: Going and returning, as not able to leave him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Gad, I'll not leave her now, till she is mine▪
Then keep her so by constant consummation.
Let Man a God do his, I'll do my part,
In spight of all her fickleness and art;
There's one sure way to fix a Widows heart.

div.head: SCENE the First. Sir Timothy's House.
div.stage: Enter Dresswell, Fopington, and five or six more disguis'd with Vizards, and dark Lanthorns.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: NOt yet! a Plague of this damn'd Widow: the Devil ow'd him an unlucky Cast, and has thrown it him to night.
sp.stage: Enter Wild. in Rapture and Ioy.
sp.p: — Hah, dear Tom, art thou come?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I saw how at her length she lay!
I saw her rising Bosome bare!

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.l: A Pox of her rising Bosome: My Dear, let's dress and about our business.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Her loose thin Robes, through which appear
A Shape design'd for Love and Play!

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.l: 'Sheart, Sir, is this a time for Rapture? 'tis almost day.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Ah, Frank, such a dear night!

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: A Pox of nights, Sir, think of this and the day to come▪ which I perceive you were too well employ'd to remember.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: The day to come!
Death, who cou'd be so dull in such dear Joys,
To think of time to come, or ought beyond 'em!
sp.p: And had I not been interrupted by Charles Meriwill, who getting drunk, had courage enough to venture on an untimely Visit▪ I'd had no more power of returning, than committing Treason: But that conjugal Lover, who will needs be my Cuckold, made me then give him way, that he might give it me another time, and so unseen I got off. But come— my disguise.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: All's still and hush, as if Nature meant to favour our designe.
'Tis well: And heark ye, my Friends, I'll proscribe you no bounds, or 〈◊〉 for I have considered if we modestly take nothing but the Writings, 'twill be easie to suspect the Thief.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Right; and since 'tis for the securing our Necks, 'tis lawful prise.— Sirrah, leave the Portmantua here.

div.stage: Enter Jervice undrest, crying out, pursu'd by some of the Thieves.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Murder, Murder! Thieves, Murder!

div.stage: Enter Wilding with his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Plague upon his Throat; set a Gag in's mouth and bind him, though he be my Uncle's chief Pimp.— So—

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Well, we have bound all within hearing in their Beds, ere they cou'd alarm their Fellows by crying out.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis well: come, follow me, like a kind Midnight-Ghost, I will conduct ye to the rich buried heaps— this door leads to my Uncles Apartment; I know each secred nook contious of Treasure.

div.stage: [All go in, leaving Jervice bound on the Stage.
Enter Sensure running half undrest as from Sir Timothy's Chamber, with his Velvet-coat on her shoulders.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Help, help! Murder! Murder!

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: What have we here, a Female bolted from Mr. Aldermans Bed?

div.stage: Holding his Lanthorn to her face.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Ah mercy, Sir, alas, I am a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: A Virgin! Gad and that may be, for any great miracles the old Gentleman can do.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Do! alas, Sir, I am none of the wicked.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: That's well.— The sanctifi'd Jilt professes Innocence, yet has the Badge of her Occupation about her neck.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Ah misfortune, I have mistook his Worships Coat for my Gown.

div.stage: A little Book drops out of her Bosome.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: What have we here? A Sermon preacht by Richard Baxter, Divine. Gad a mercy, Sweetheart, thou art a hopeful Member of the true Protestant Cause.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Alack, how the Saints may be scandaliz'd! I went but to tuck his Worship in.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: And comment upon the Text a little, which I suppose may be increase and multiply.— Here, gag and bind her.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I am with Child!

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Then you'll go neer to miscarry of a Babe of Grace.

div.stage: Enter Wild. Fop. and others, leading in Sir Timothy in his Night-gown and Night-caps.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Gentlemen, why Gentlemen, I beseech you use a Conscience in what you do, and have a feeling of what you go about.— Pity my Age.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Damn'd beggarly Conscience, and needless Pity—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
Oh fearful!— But, Gentlemen, what is't you designe? is it a genera● Massacar, pray, or am I the onely person aim'd at as a Sacrifice for the Nation? know, and all the World knows, how many Plots have been laid against my self
both by men, women, and children, the Diabolical Emissaries of the Pope.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How, Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay, Gentlemen, not but I love and honour his Holiness with all my Soul; and if his Grace did but know what I have done for him, d'ye see—

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: You done for the Pope, Sirrah! why what have you done for the Pope?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why, Sir, an't like ye, I have done you great service, very great service, for I have been, d'ye see, in a small Tryal I had, the cause and occasion of invalidating the Evidence to that degree, that I suppose no Jury in Christendom will ever have the impudence to believe 'em hereafter, shou'd they swear against his Holiness himself, and all the Conclave of Cardinals.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And yet you plot on still, cabal, treat, and keep open debauch, for all the Renegado-Tories and old Commonwealths-men to carry on the good Cause.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Alas, what signifies that? You know, Gentlemen, that I have such a strange and natural agility in turning,— I shall whip about yet, and leave 'em all in the lurch.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely; but at this time we shall not take your word for that.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Bloody minded men, are you resolv'd to assassinate me then?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You trifle, Sir, and know our business better, than to think we come to take your Life, which wou'd not advantage a Dog, much less any Party or Person,— Come, come, your Keys, your Keys.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Aye, aye, discover, discover your Money, Sir, your ready—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Money, Sir! good lack, is that all?

Why what a Beast was I, not knowing of your coming, to put out all my Money last week to Alderman Draw-tooth! Alack, alack, what shift shall I make now to accommodate you?— But if you please to come again to morrow—

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: A shamming Rogue; the right Sneer and Grin of a dissembling Whig. Come, come, deliver, Sir; we are for no Rhetorick, but ready Money.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hold, I beseech you, Gentlemen, not so loud: for there is a Lord, a most considerable person and a stranger, honours my house to night; I wou'd not for the world his Lordship shou'd be disturb'd.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Take no care for him, he's fast bound, and all his Retinue.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, bound! my Lord bound, and all his People! Undone, undone, disgrac'd! What will the Polanders say, that I shou'd expose their Embassadour to this disrespect and affront?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Bind him, and take away his Keys.

div.stage: They bind him hand and foot, and take his Keys out of his bosome. Exeunt all.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Aye, aye, what you please, Gentlemen, since my Lord's bound.— Oh what Recompence can I make for so unhospitable usage? I am a most unfortunate Magistrate!— Hah, who's there, Iervice? Alas, art thou here too? What, canst not speak? But 'tis no matter and I were dumb too: for what Speech or Harangue will serve to beg my pardon of my Lord?— And then my Heiress, Iervice, aye, my rich Heiress, why she'll be ravisht, oh Heavens, ravisht! The young Rogues will have no mercy, Iervice; nay, perhaps as thou sayest, they'll carry her away.— Oh that thought! Gad I'd rather the City-Charter were lost. [Enter some with bags of Money.— Why Gentlemen, rob like Christians, Gentlemen.
〈◊〉, do you mutter, Dog?

Not in the least, Sir, not in the least; onely a Conscience, Sir, in all things does well.— Barbarous Rogues! [They go out all again.] Here's you Arbitrary Power, Iervice; here's the rule of the Sword now for you: These are your Tory Rogues, your Tantivie Roysters; but we shall cry quits with you, Rascals, erelong: and if we do come to our old Trade of Plunder and Sequestration, we will so handle ye— 〈…〉 neither Prince, Peer, nor Prelate. Oh, I long to have a Voice at your fat Church-men, your Crape-Gown-orums.

div.stage: Enter Wild. and the rest, with more Bags.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Prize, a Prize, my Lads, in ready Guinies! Contribution, my Beloved.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Nay then 'tis lawful Prize, in spight of Ignoramus and all his Tribe.— What hast thou there?

div.stage: [To Fop. who enters with a bag full of Papers.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: A whole Bag of Knavery, damn'd Sedition, Libels, Treason, Successions, Rights and Priviledges, with a new-fashion'd Oath of Abjuration, call'd the Association.— Ah Rogue, what will you say when these shall be made publick?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Say, Sir? why I'll deny it, Sir: for what Jury will believe so wise a Magistrate as I, cou'd communicate such Secrets to such as you? I'll say you forg'd 'em, and put 'em in,— or print every one of 'em, and own 'em, as long as they were writ and publisht in London, Sir.) Come, come, the World is not so bad yet, but a man may speak Treason within the Walls of London, thanks be to God, and honest conscientious Jury-men. And as for the Money, Gentlemen, take notice you rob the Party.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, come, carry off the Booty, and prithee remove that Rubbish of the Nation out of the way.— Your Servant, Sir.— So, away with it to Dresswell's Lodgings, his Coach is at the door ready to receive it.

div.stage: They carry off Sir Timothy, and others take up the Bags, and go out with 'em.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Well, you are sure you have all you came for?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: All's safe, my Lads, the Writings all.—

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Come, let's away then.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Away? what meanst thou? is there not a Lord to be found bound in his bed, and all his People? Come, come, dispatch, and each man bind his fellow.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: We had better follow the Baggage, Captain.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, we have not done so ill, but we dare shew our faces. Come, come, to binding.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: And who shall bind the last man?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Honest Laboir, d'ye hear, Sirrah? you got drunk and lay in your Clothes under the Hall-table; d'ye conceive me? Look to't, ye Rascal, and carry things discreetly, or you'll all be hang'd, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: So; now will I i'th morning to Charlot, and give her such a character of her Lover, as if she have resentment, makes her mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: [calls within.] Ho, Ienkin, Roger, Simon! where are these Rogues? None left alive to come to my assistance? So ho, ho, ho! Rascals, Sluggards, Drones! So ho, ho, ho!

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: So, now's my Que— and stay, I am not yet sober.

div.stage: Puts himself into a drunken posture.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Dogs, Rogues, none hear me? Fire, fire, fire!

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Water, water, I say: for I am damnable dry.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ha, who's there?

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: What doleful voice is that?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What art thou, friend or foe?

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Very direful— why what the Devil art thou?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: If thou'rt a friend, approach, approach the wretched.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Wretched! What art thou, Ghost, Hobgobling, or walking Spirit?

div.stage: Reeling in with a Lanthorn in's hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh, neither, neither, but meer mortal Sir Timothy Treat-all, robb'd and bound.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: How, our generous Host?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, one of my Lords Servants! Alas, alas, how cam'st thou to escape?

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Ene by Miracle, Sir, by being drunk and falling asleep under the Hall-table with your Worships Dog Tory, till just now a Dream of Small-beer wakt me; and crawling from my Kennel to secure the black Jack, I stumb'ed upon this Lanthorn, which I took for one, till I found a Candle in't, which helps me to serve your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I say; for I scorn to be so uncivil to be unbound before his Lordship: therefore run, Friend, to his Honours Chamber, for he, alas, is confin'd too.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: What, and leave his worthy Friend in distress? by no means, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well then, come, let's to my Lord, whom if I be not asham'd to look in the face, I am an errant Sarazan.

div.stage: He discover'd sitting in a Chair bound his Vallet bound by him; to them Sir Timothy and Laboir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Peace, Sirrah, for sure I hear some coming.— Villains, Rogues! I care not for my self, but the good pious Alderman.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Wonderful goodness, for me! alas, my Lord, this sight will break my heart.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Sir Timothy safe! nay then I do forgive 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord, I've heard of your rigid fate.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It is my custom, Sir, to pray an hour or two in my Chamber, before I go to bed; and having pray'd that drowsie Slave asleep, the Thieves broke in upon us unawares, I having laid my Sword aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens, at his Prayers! damn'd Ruffians, and wou'd they not stay till you had said your Prayers?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By no perswasion.— Can you not guess who they shou'd be, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh, some damn'd Tory-rory Rogues, you may be sure, to rob a▪ man at his Prayers! why what will this world come to?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Let us not talk, Sir, but pursue 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Pursue 'em? alas, they're past our reach by this time.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, they are neerer than you imagine:
〈…〉 each corner of your house, I'll warrant.
Think ye so, my Lord? Aye, this comes of keeping Open House; which makes so many shut up their doors at Dinner-time.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Good morrow, Gentlemen! what was the Devil broke loose to night?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Onely some of his Imps, Sir, sawcy Varlets, insupportable Rascals.— But well, my Lord, now I have seen your Lordship at liberty, I'll leave you to your rest, and go see what harm this nights work has done.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I have a little business, Sir, and will take this time to dispatch it in; my Servants shall to bed, though 'tis already day.— I'll wait on you at Dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Your time: my House and all I have is yours; and so I take my leave of your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Now for my angry Maid, the young Charlot;
'Twill be a task to soften her to peace:
She is all new and gay, young as the Morn,
Blushing as tender Rose-buds on their stalks,
Pregnant with sweets, for the next Sun to ravish.
— Come, thou shalt along with me, I'll trust thy friendship.

div.stage: She is discover'd dressing, with Betty.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Methinks I'm up as early as if I had a mind to what I'm going to do, marry this old rich Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: And you do well to lose no time.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Ah, Betty, and cou'd thy prudence prefer an old Husband, because rich, before so young, so handsome, and so soft a Lover as Wilding?

sp.speaker: Bet:
sp.p: I know not that, Madam; but I verily believe the way to keep your young Lover, is to marry this old one: for what Youth and Beauty cannot purchase, Money and Quality may.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Aye, but to be oblig'd to lie with such a Beast; aye, there's the Devil

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Ah, when I find the difference of their Embraces,
The soft dear Arms of Wilding round my neck,
From those cold feeble ones of this old Dotard;
When I shall meet, instead of Tom's warm Kisses,
A hollow pair of thin blue wither'd Lips,
Trembling with Palsie, stinking with Disease,
By Age and Nature baracado'd up
With a kind Nose and Chin;
What fancy or what thought can make my hours supportable?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: What? why six thousand pound a year, Mistriss.
He'll quickly die and leave you rich, and then do what you please.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Die! no, he's too temperate.— Sure these Whigs, Betty, believe there's no Heaven, they take such care to live so long in this world.— No, he'll out-live me.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: In grace a God he may be hang'd first, Mistriss.— Ha, one knoc 〈◊〉 lieve 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I cannot bring my heart to like this business;
One sight of my dear Tom wou'd turn the scale.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Who's there?

div.stage: Enter Sir Tim. joyful; Dian. walks away.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: 'Tis I, impatient I, who with the Sun have welcom'd in the day;
This happy day to be inroll'd
In Rubrick-letters, and in Gold.
— Hum, I am profoundly eloquent this morning.
— Fair Excellence, I approach—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Like Physick in a morning next one's heart;
Which though 'tis necessary, is most filthy loathsome.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: What, do you turn away, bright Sun of Beauty?
— Hum, I'm much upon the Suns and Days this morning.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: It will not down.

div.stage: [Turning to him, looks on him, and turns away.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Alas, ye Gods, am I dispis'd and scorn'd?
Did I for this, ponder upon the Question,
Whether I shou'd be King or Alderman?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: If I must marry him, give him patience to endure the Cuckolding, good Heaven.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Heaven! did she name Heaven, Betty?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I think she did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I do not like that: What need has she to think of Heaven upon her Wedding-day?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Marriage is a sort of hanging, Sir; and I was onely making a short Prayer before Execution.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh, is that all? Come, come, we'll let that alone till we are abed, that we have nothing else to do.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Not much, I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: And let us, Fair one, haste; the Parson stays: besides, that heap of Scandal may prevent us,— I mean my Nephew.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: A Pox upon him now for naming Wilding.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, weep at naming my ungracious Nephew? Nay, then I am provokt— Look on this Head, this wise and reverend Head; I'd have ye know, it has been taken measure on to fit it to a Crown, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: A Halter rather.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Aye, and it fits it too: and am I slighted, I that shall receive Billet Deux from Infantas? 'tis most uncivil and impolitick.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I hope he's mad, and then I reign alone.
Pardon me, Sir, that parting Tear I shed indeed at naming Wilding,
Of whom my foolish heart has now tane leave,
And from this moment is intirely yours.

div.stage: Gives him her hand, they go out.
Enter Charlot, led by Fopington, followed by Mrs. Clacket.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Stay, my heart misgives me I shall be undone.— Ah, whither was I going?

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Do, stay till the news arrives that he is married to her that had his company to night, my Lady Galliard.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Oh take heed, lest you sin doubly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: By Heaven, 'tis true, he past the night with her.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: All night? what cou'd they find to do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: A very proper Question: I'll warrant you they were not idle, Madam.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Oh no; they lookt and lov'd, and vow'd and lov'd, and swore eternal Friendship.— Haste, haste, and lead me to the Church, the Altar; I'll put it past my power to love him more.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Oh, how you charm me!

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Yet what art thou? a stranger to my heart.
Wherefore, ah why, on what occasion shou'd I?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Acquaintance, 'tis enough, I know him, Madam, and I hope my word will be taken for a greater matter i'th' City: In troth you're beholding to the Gentleman for marrying you; your Reputation's gone.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: How, am I not honest then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Marry Heaven forbid! But who that knows you have been a single hour in Wilding's hands, that wou'd not swear you'd lost your Maidenhead? And back again I'm sure you dare not go unmarried; that wou'd be a fine History to be sung to your eternal fame in a Ballad.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Right; and you see Wilding has left you for the Widow, to whom perhaps you'll shortly hear he's married.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Oh, you trifle, Sir; lead on.

div.stage: They going out, meet Sir Anthony with Musick: they return.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
