sp.p: Come, come, Gentlemen, this is the House, and this the window belonging to my Ladies Bed-chamber: Come, come, let's have some neat, soft, brisk, languishing, sprightly Air now.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Old Meriwill— how shall I pass by him?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: So, here's Company too; 'tis very well— Not have the Boy? I'll warrant this does the business.— Come, come, screw up your Chitterling.
sp.l: — Hold, hold a little,— Good morrow, my Lady Galliard,
— Give your Ladyship joy.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: What do I hear, my Lady Galliard joy'd?

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: How, married her already?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Oh, yes he has. Lovely and false, hast thou deceiv'd my Faith?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Oh Heavens, Mr. Fopington, she faints— ah me!

div.stage: Enter Wilding and Dresswell disguis'd as before.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ah, Musick at Galliard's door!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Good morrow, Sir Charles Meriwill; give your Worship and your fair Lady joy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Hah, Meriwill married the Widow?

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: No matter; prithee advance and mind thy own affairs.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Advance, and not inquire the meaning on't!
Bid me not eat, when Appetite invites me;
Not draw, when branded with the name of Coward;
Nor love, when Youth and Beauty meets my eyes.— Hah!—

div.stage: Sees Sir Charles come into the Belconey undrest.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Good morrow, Uncle. Gentlemen I thank ye: Here, drink the Kings Health, with my Royal Master's the Duke.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Heaven bless your Honour, and your vertuous Bride.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Wilding! undone.

div.stage: [Shelters Charlot that she may not see Wilding.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Death and the Devil, Meriwill above?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Hah, the Boys Rival here! By George, here may be breathing this morning.— No matter, here's two to two; come, Gentlemen, you must in.

div.stage: Thrusts the Musick in, and goes in.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.p: Is't not what you expected? nay, what you wisht?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What then? it comes too suddenly upon me—
Ere my last kiss was cold upon her lips,
Before the pantings of her Breast were laid,
rais'd by her Joys with me; Oh damn'd deluding Woman!

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.l: Be wise, and do not ruine where you love.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nay, if thou com'st to reasoning, thou hast lost me.

div.stage: Breaks from him and runs in.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I say 'twas Wilding's voice, and I will follow it.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.l: How, Madam, wou'd you after him?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Nay, force me not: By Heaven I'll cry a Rape,
Unless you let me go.— Not after him!
Yes to th'infernal Shades.— Unhand me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: How, Madam, have you then design'd my ruine?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Oh, trust me, Sir, I am a Maid of Honour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.l: So; a Murrain of your Projects, we're all undone now: For my part
I'll en'● after her, and deny to have any hand in the business.

sp.speaker: Fop.
sp.p: Damn all ill ●●ck, was ever man thus Fortune-bit, that he shou'd cross my hopes just in the nick?— But shall I lose her thus? No Gad, I'll after her; and come the worst, I have an Impudence shall out-face a Middlesex- Jury, and out-swear a Discoverer.

div.stage: Enter Lady Galliard pursued by Sir Charles, and Footman.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Sirrah, run to my Lord Mayors and require some of his Officers to assist me instantly; and d'ye hear, Rascal, bar up my doors, and let none of his mad Crew enter.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: William, you may stay, William.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I say, obey me, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Sirrah, I say— know your Lord and Master.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Was ever woman teaz'd thus? pursue me not.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: You are mistaken, I'm disobedient grown,
sp.p: Since we became one Family; and when I've us'd you thus a week or two, you will grow weary of this peevish fooling.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Malicious thing, I wo'not, I am resolv'd I'll tire thee out meerly in spight to have the better of thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Gad I'm as resolv'd as you, and do your worst:
For I'm resolv'd never to quit thy house.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: But Malice, there are Officers, Magistrates i'th' City, that will not see me us'd thus, and will be here anon.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Magistrates! why they shall be welcome, if they be honest and loyal; if not, they may be hang'd in Heavens good time.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Are you resolv'd to be thus obstinate?
Fully resolv'd to make this way your Conquest?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Most certainly, I'll keep you honest to your word, my Dear, I've Witness—

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: You will?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: You'll find it so.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Then know, if thou darest marry me, I will so plague thee, be so reveng'd for all those tricks thou'st playd me—
sp.l: — Dost thou not dread the Vengeance Wives can take?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Not at all: I'll trust thy stock of Beauty with thy Wit..

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Death, I will cuckold thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why then I shall be free o'th' Reverend City.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Then I will game without cessation, till I've undone thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Do, that all the Fops of empty heads and pockets, may know where to be sure of a Cully; and may they rook ye till ye lose, and fret, and chafe, and rail those youthful Eyes to sinking; watch your fair Face to pale and withered leanness.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Then I will never let thee bed with me, but when I please.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: For that, see who'll petition first, and then I'll change for new ones every night.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Madam, here's Mr. Wilding at the door, and will not be deni'd 〈…〉

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Hah, Wilding! Oh my eternal shame! now thou hast done thy 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Now for a struggle 'twixt your Love and Honour.
— Yes, here's the Bar to all my Happiness,
You wou'd be left to the wide World and Love,
To Infamy, to Scandal, and to Wilding;
But I have too much Honour in my Passion,
To let you loose to Ruine: Consider and be wise.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Oh, he has toucht my heart too sensibly.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.l: [within.] As far as good Manners goes I'm yours;
But when you press indecently to Ladies Chambers, civil
Questions ought to be askt, I take it, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: To find him here, will make him mad with Jealousie, and in the fit he'll utter all he knows; Oh, Guilt, what art thou?

div.stage: Enter Sir Anth. Wild. and Dress.

sp.speaker: Dress.
sp.l: Prithee, dear Wilding, moderate thy Passion.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By Heaven, I will; she shall not have the pleasure to see I am concern'd.— Morrow, Widow; you are early up, you mean to thrive I see, you're like a Mill that grinds with every Wind.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Hah, Wilding this, that past last night at Sir Timothy's for a man of Quality? Oh, give him way, Wilding's my Friend, my Dear, and now I'm sure I have the advantage of him in thy love. I can forgive a hasty word or two.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I thank thee, Charles— What, you are married then?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: I hope you've no exception to my choice.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: False woman, dost thou glory in thy perfidy?
— Yes, Faith, I've many exceptions to him—
Had you lov'd me, you'd pitcht upon a Blockhead,
Some spruce gay fool of Fortune, and no more,
Who would have taken so much care of his own ill-favour'd
Person, he shou'd have had no time to have minded yours,
But left it to the care of some fond longing Lover.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Death, he will tell him all! [aside.] Oh, you are merry, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: No, but thou art wonderous false,
False as the Love and Joys you feign'd last night.

div.stage: [In a soft tone aside to her.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Oh, Sir, be tender of those treacherous minutes.
— If this be all you have to say to me—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Faith, Madam, you have us'd me scurvily,
To marry and not give me notice.
— Curse on thee, did I onely blow the Fire▪
To warm another Lover?

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Perjur'd— was't not by your advice I marry'd?
— Oh where was then your Love?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: So soon did I advise,
Didst thou invite me to the Feast of Love,
To snatch away my Joys as soon as tasted;
〈…〉 was then your Modesty and sense of Honour?

div.stage: [Aside to her in a low tone.

sp.l: Aye, where indeed, when you so quickly vanquisht?
〈◊〉 I find are come prepar'd to rail.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: No, 'twas with thee to make my last effort against your scorn.
And this I hop'd, when all my Vows and Love,
When all my Languishments cou'd nought prevail,
Had made ye mine for ever.

div.stage: Enter Sir Anthony pulling in Sir Timothy and Diana.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: ‛ Morrow, Charles, ' Morrow to your Ladyship: Charles, bid Sir Timothy welcome; I met him luckily at the door, and am resolv'd none of my Friends shall pass this joyful day without giving thee Joy, Charles, and drinking my Ladies Health.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Hah, my Uncle here so early?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What has your Ladyship serv'd me so? How finely I had been mumpt now, if I had not took heart a grace and shew'd your Ladyship trick for trick: for I have been this morning about some such business of Life too, Gentlemen; I am married to this fair Lady, the Daughter and Heiress of Sir Nicholas Gettall, Knight and Alderman.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Hah, married to Diana!
How fickle is the Faith of common women?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hum, Who's here, my Lord? What, I see you Lordship has found the way already to the fair Ladies; but I hope your Lordship will do my Wedding-dinner the honour to grace it with your presence.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I shall not fail, Sir.
A Pox upon him, he'll discover all.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: I must own, Sir Timothy, you have made the better choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I cou'd not help my destiny; Marriages are made in Heaven, you know.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Stand off, and let me loose as are my Griefs, which can no more be bounded: Oh let me face the perjur'd, false, forsworn!

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Fair Creature, who is't that you seek with so much sorrow?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Thou, thou fatally fair Inchantress.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Charlot! Nay then I am discover'd.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Alas, what wou'dst thou?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: That which I cannot have, thy faithless Husband.
Be judge, ye everlasting Powers of Love,
Whether he more belongs to her or me.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: How, my Nephew claim'd? Why how now, Sirrah, have you been dabling here?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: By Heaven, I know her not.— Heark ye, Widow, this is some trick of yours, and 'twas well laid: and Gad, she's so pretty, I cou'd find in my heart to take her at her word.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Vile man, this will not pass your falshood off.
Sure 'tis some Art to make me jealous of him,
To find how much I value him.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.l: Death, I'll have the forgery out;
sp.p: — Tell me, thou pretty weeping Hypocrite, who was it set thee on to lay 〈…〉 me?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: To you! Alas, who are you? for till this moment I never saw your 〈◊〉▪

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: Mad as the Seas when all the Winds are raging.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Aye, aye, Madam, stark mad! Poor Soul— Neighbour, pray let her lie i'th' dark, d'ye hear.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How came you, pretty one, to lose your Wits thus?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: With loving, Sir, strongly, with too much loving.
— Will you not let me see the lovely false one?
For I am told you have his heart in keeping.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.l: Who is he? pray describe him.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: A thing just like a Man, or rather Angel!
He speaks, and looks, and loves, like any God!
All fine and gay, all manly, and all sweet:
And when he swears he loves, you wou'd swear too
That all his Oaths were true.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Who is she? some one who knows her and is wiser, speak— you, Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: Since I must speak, there comes the man of Mischief:— 'Tis you I mean, for all your learing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clack.
sp.p: I never knew your Nephew was a Lord: Has his Honour made him forget his Honesty?

div.stage: [Charl. runs and catches him in her Arms.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I have thee, and I'll die thus grasping thee:
Thou art my own, no Power shall take thee from me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Never, thou truest of thy Sex, and dearest,
Thou soft, thou kind, thou constant Sufferer,
This moment end thy fears; for I am thine.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: May I believe thou art not married then?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How can I, when I'm yours?
How cou'd I, when I love thee more than Life?
— Now, Madam, I'm reveng'd on all your scorn.
— And, Uncle, all your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why, what are you indeed my Nephew, Thomas?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am Tom Wilding, Sir, that once bore some such Title, till you discarded me, and left me to live upon my Wits.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What, and are you no Polish Embassadour then incognito?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, Sir, nor you no King Elect, but must e'en remain as you were ever, Sir, a most seditious pestilent old Knave; one that deludes the Rabble with your Politicks, then leave 'em to be hang'd, as they deserve, for silly mutinous Rebels.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I'll peach the Rogue, and then he'll be hang'd in course, because he's a Tory. One comfort is, I have couzen'd him of his rich Heiress; for I am married, Sir, to Mrs. Charlot.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Rather Diana, Sir; I wish you Joy: See here's Charlot! I was not such a Fool to trust such Blessings with the Wicked.
How Mrs. Dy Ladyfi'd! This is an excellent way of disposing an old 〈◊〉▪
How, have I married a Strumpet then?

sp.speaker: Dial.
sp.p: You give your Nephews Mistriss, Sir, too coarse a name: 'Tis true, I lov'd him, onely him, and was true to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Undone, undone! I shall ne'r make Guildhall-speech more; but he shall hang for't, if there be ere a Witness to be had between this and Salamancha for Money.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Do your worst, Sir; Witnesses are out of fashion now, Sir, thanks to your Ignoramus Juries.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Then I'm resolv'd to dis-inherit him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: See, Sir, that's past your skill too, thanks to my last nights Ingenuity: they're [shews him the Writings] sign'd, seal'd, and deliver'd in the presence of, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Bear Witness, 'twas he that robb'd me last night.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: We bear Witness, Sir, we know of no such matter we. I thank you for that, Sir, wou'd you make Witnesses of Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No matter for that, I'll have him hang'd, nay drawn and quarter'd.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What, for obeying your Commands, and living on my Wits?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis a cleer case you can neither hang him nor blame him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll propose fairly now, if you'll be generous and pardon all: I'll render your Estate back during Life, and put the Writings in Sir Anthony Meriwill's and Sir Charles● his hands.—
sp.l: I have a Fortune here that will maintain me,
Without so much as wishing for your death.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: This is but Reason.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: With this Proviso, that he makes not use on't to promote any mischief to the King and Government.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Good and just.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hum, I'd as good quietly agree to't, as lose my Credit by making a noise.— Well, Tom, I pardon all, and will be Friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: See, my dear Creature, even this hard old man is mollifi'd at last into good nature; yet you'll still be cruel.

sp.speaker: L. Gall.
sp.p: No, your unwearied Love at last has vanquisht me. Here, be as happy as a Wife can make ye— One last look more, and then— be gone fond Love.

div.stage: Sighing and looking on Wilding, giving Sir Charles her hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you must receive Diana too; she is a cheerful witty Girl, and handsome, one that will be a Comfort to your Age, and bring no scandal home. Live peaceably, and do not trouble your decrepid Age with business of State.
sp.l: Let all things in their own due order move,
Let Caesar be the Kingdoms care and love:
Let the Hot-headed Mutineers petition,
And meddle in the Rights of Just Succession;
But may all honest hearts as one agree
To bless the King, and Royal Albanie.

div.head: EPILOGUE, Written by a Person of Quality. SPOKEN by Mrs. BOTELER.
div.l: MY Part, I fear, will take with but a few,
A rich young Heiress to her first Love true!
'Tis damn'd unnatural, and past enduring,
Against the fundamental Laws of Whoring.
Marrying's the Mask, which Modesty assures,
Helps to get new, and covers old Amours;
And Husband sounds so dull to a Town-Bride,
You now-a-days condemn him ere he's try'd;
Ere in his Office he's confirm'd Possessor,
Like Trincaloes you chuse him a Successor,
In the gay spring of Love, when free from doubts,
With early shoots his Velvet Forehead sprouts.
Like a poor Parson bound to hard Indentures,
You make him pay his First-fruits ere he enters.
But for short Carnivals of stoln good Cheer,
You're after forc'd to keep Lent all the Year;
Till brought at last to a starving Nuns condition,
You break into our Quarters for Provision:
Invade Fop-corner with your glaring Beauties,
And Vice our Loyal Subjects from their Duties.
Pray, Ladies, ●ave that Province to our care;
A Fool is the Fee-simple of a Player,
In which we Women claim a double share.
〈◊〉 things the Men are Rulers made;
〈…〉 Woodcocks is our proper Trade.
If by Stage-Fops they a poor Living get,
We can grow rich, thanks to our Mother Wit,
By the more natural Blockheads in the Pit.
Take then the Wits, and all their useless Prattles;
But as for Fools, they are our Goods and Chattels.
Return, Ingrates, to your first Haunt the Stage;
We taught your Youth, and help'd your feeble Age.
What is't you see in Quality we want?
What can they give you which we cannot grant?
We have their Pride, their Frolicks, and their Paint.
We feel the same Youth dancing in our Blood;
Our dress as gay— All underneath as good.
Most men have found us hitherto more true,
And, if we're not abus'd by some of you,
We●re full as fair— perhaps as wholesome too.
But if at best our hopeful Sport and Trade is,
And nothing now will serve you but great Ladies;
May question'd Marriages your Fortune be,
And Lawyers drain your Pockets more than we:
May Iudges puzzle a clear Case with Laws,
And Musquetoon at last decide the Cause.
